 Relative Valuation There are two ways in which we can adapt relative valuation to the complex companies we have examined in this chapter.
The first is to accept the reality that we will never find comparable firms, defined in terms of business mix.
If we do that, we must either find firms that have similar cash flow, growth, and risk characteristics, or control for differences on those dimensions.
The second method is an extension of the sum-of-the-parts relative valuation we described earlier, with more attention paid to adjusting for the characteristics of complex companies.

 Extended Pricing In most relative valuations, analysts stay within a sector to make their valuation judgments.
Thus, a software company is compared to other software companies, and a steel company to other steel companies.
Implicitly, we are assuming that firms within a sector share enough risk, growth, and cash flow characteristics to be priced similarly.
When a company operates in many different sectors or businesses, this type of relative valuation becomes much more difficult.
However, there is no reason why we cannot expand our relative valuation sample to include firms that are dissimilar from the one we are valuing, as long as we control for differences in valuation fundamentals when we make our comparisons.

 In practical terms, we can try to modify the multiples we use for fundamentals (as is the case when we use PEG ratios) or use regressions that explicitly adjust for differences across companies.
In January 2009, for instance, a regression of price-to-book ratios of the 100 largest market cap companies in the U.S., against return on equity, beta, and expected growth in earnings per share (over the next five years), yielded the following output:P/BV = 1.57 + 7.67ROE + 8.91Expected Growth in EPS − 1.64beta R2 = 62%If we wanted to value GE, a company with almost no directly comparable firms, we would plug in the values of the independent variables for GE (ROE = 11%, beta = 1.05, expected growth = 7%) into this regression to get a predicted price-to-book value multiple for GE:In January 2009, GE was trading at $11.12 per share and had a book value of equity per share of $9.93, resulting in a price-to-book ratio of 1.12.
This would have it undervalued by about 20%.

 Modified Sum-of-the-Parts Pricing Earlier in this chapter, we described how some analysts value companies that operate in multiple businesses by applying multiples to the earnings or revenues generated by each business.
Although there are significant limitations in how they use this approach, it can be adapted effectively if we go through five steps:prior to allocations to value individual businesses.
We can adjust the consolidated value for these costs in one of two ways.
The first is to look at the costs as a proportion of after-tax operating income (for the entire firm) and to reduce the value by that same amount.
Thus, if centralized costs amount to $2 billion on after-tax operating income of $20 billion, we would reduce the consolidated value by 10%.
The second way is to apply a multiple to the consolidated costs themselves to arrive at a value.
One simple way to derive this multiple is to look at the value we are estimating for the rest of the company and the multiple of operating income it represents.
The second adjustment is for cross-holdings, because how they are accounted for can distort the values we obtain from relative valuation.
The adjustments we make for minority holdings mirror the ones we made to intrinsic value; we have to estimate the value of these holdings and add that value to the consolidated value.
With majority holdings, the income reported by business is the consolidated income; we have to subtract the estimated value of minority interests.
If it is just parent company income, we have to value the majority holdings separately and add them to the consolidated value.Previously we valued United Technologies using discounted cash flow models.
To value the company on a relative valuation basis, we will begin with a breakdown of revenues, EBITDA, operating income, and capital invested by business, as shown in Table 17.13.Table 17.13 Scaling Variables by DivisionThus, our choices on multiples are narrowed to one of these four variables, with enterprise value (rather than equity value) being estimated.
To decide which multiple (EV/revenues, EV/EBITDA, EV/EBIT, or EV/capital) to use in the valuation, we look at the publicly traded companies within each business and try to explain differences across companies (within each business) using all four multiples.
We then choose the multiple that has the most significant explanatory power (the highest R-squared on the sector regression) for each business.
Table 17.14 summarizes the multiple used by business, and the regression equation that generates the statistical significance.Table 17.14 Choosing a Multiple for a BusinessFinally, we use the multiple chosen in each business, in conjunction with the sector regression, to estimate a value for each of United Technologies’ different businesses, as shown in Table 17.15.Table 17.15 Estimated Relative Value by BusinessAs with the disaggregated discounted cash flow valuation, we have to deal with corporate expenses of $408 million, and we have two choices.
One is to use a discounted cash flow approach to estimate the value; this yields $4,587 million.
The other is to stay within a relative valuation framework and apply a multiple to this expense.
In fact, the value ($74,340) that we have estimated for the operating divisions of UT in Table 17.15 is about 9.25 times the cumulated operating income ($8,034 million) across the divisions.
Applying this multiple to the corporate expenses results in a capitalized value of about $3,775 million.
When subtracted from the overall value, this yields a value for the operating assets of $70,565 million, a little lower than the values we estimated using theintrinsic value approaches.
Note that the rest of the adjustments (adding cash, subtracting debt and minority interests, and adjusting for options outstanding) still have to be made to derive equity value per share.

 User/Subscriber/Customer Companies In the last decade, we seem to have shifted into an age when companies measure their success based on the number of subscribers, customers, and users that they have, rather than on the traditional metrics of total revenues and cash flows.
While we remain committed to the notion that value ultimately comes from cash flows, the way we build up to those cash flows, in companies like Uber, Facebook, and Netflix, is often through their users or subscribers.
In pricing, the shift has been even more stark, with many investors pricing social media companies on the number of users that they have, rather than as multiples of total revenues and earnings.
In this section, we look at the dark side of this shift in terms of valuation and pricing practices and perhaps provide a better way of thinking about how best to value and price users or subscribers.

 The Rise of the User There is no company that captures the shift in focus in business better than Facebook.
Its meteoric rise in value can be traced best to its mammoth user base, with close to 2 billion users by mid-2017.
To give the company its intrinsic value due, those users have translated into an online advertising revenue that grows at hefty rates in each period and a high operating margin (36% in 2017).
There are other social media companies, younger and less tested than Facebook, that offer only one-half of the equation, which is lots of users, but they don't have the revenues and earnings to back up these users.
This is the case, for instance, with Twitter and Snap, in 2017, though both companies would add that it is only a matter of time before both are delivered.

 It is not just the social media companies that build their value up from users.
Netflix, another company whose market value has soared, often emphasizes the growth in its subscriber base more than it talks about revenues or profits in each earnings report, as it exceeded a hundred million subscribers in 2017.
Companies that used to build their valuations around conventional business metrics seem to have noticed the market’s liking for unit growth.
Amazon has invested heavily in Amazon Prime, its subscription membership model with 85 million subscribers in 2017, and seems to be using it as a wedge to create more growth and value in its retail and entertainment businesses.
Microsoft and Adobe, which used to be conventional software companies that built growth around selling upgrades to existing software, have adopted subscription models, Office 365 for Microsoft and Creative Cloud for Adobe.

 If you are an investor or analyst looking at these companies, you have two choices.
One is to stick with the conventional aggregated models and to try to capture the benefits of users and subscribers in revenue growth and operating margin, and the cost of acquiring these users in reinvestment.
The other is to estimate the value of a user or subscriber, using intrinsic valuefirst principles or standard pricing practices, and then aggregating up to the value of a company.
In my view, there are benefits to both, and because there is no reason that using one approach precludes you from using the other, perhaps doing both makes sense.Valuation Issues Given the characteristics of user-/subscriber-based companies, you could start constructing valuation models that try to incorporate these characteristics.
The issues, though, that bedevil user-based valuation are often not theoretical but are related to information disclosure and accounting practices.Information disclosure (or non-disclosure): As you will see in the next few sections, there is no magic to valuing a user.
In fact, conventional valuation models can be easily adapted to estimate the value of a user to Facebook, a rider for Uber, and a subscriber in Netflix.
That said, the information needed to value these units is often either held back or opaquely provided by companies.
It is ironic that companies that are quick to tout the number of users they have and ask to be priced on that number are unwilling to share information about those users that investors need to better judge their value or price.
The accounting rule writers might want to consider what investors need to better assess unit value when they write rules specifically for user- or subscription-based companies.
Accounting inconsistencies: Coupled with the information non-disclosure is another problem that we highlighted for companies with intangible assets.
Just as accountants take the biggest capital expenditures (R&D) made by technology and pharmaceutical firms and treat them as operating expenses, the biggest investment for future growth made at user-based and subscription-based companies is the money spent in acquiring new users and subscribers, and that expenditure is routinely expensed.
As with pharmaceutical companies, you can then argue that the income at user-based companies is understated and that the biggest assets that these companies have is not on their books.
In fact, we will argue that the problem is more difficult to solve at these companies than it was at technology and pharmaceutical companies, because unlike R&D, which is separately reported as an operating expense, and thus can be recategorized as a capital expense, the costs of acquiring new users is hidden in SG&A expenses and often very difficult (if not impossible) to separate.
User Diversity: Not all users and subscribers are of equal value.
Thus, while the subscription revenue is roughly the same across subscribers for Netflix, which charges similar prices across the globe, the value of a user can vary widely across geographies and within the same market for companies like Uber.
For instance, we will be valuing users/riders at Uber in the next section, but some Uber users use far more of its service than others and thus should be valued more highly.
In fact, one proxy for risk in a user model might be the disparity in values across users, because a company that derives 90% of its value from 10% of its users is built on a riskier base than a company that has a more uniform value distribution.
Here again, companies have not been forthcoming in providing more information on differences across users, choosing instead to report total user numbers and average usage statistics.As you can see, not only have analysts and valuation practice not caught up with the shift to users and subscribers at some companies, but neither have accounting rules and information disclosure laws.

 The Dark Side of Valuation Some analysts have tentatively stepped up their efforts to value and price users, at companies like Facebook, Netflix, and even Amazon, but often for the wrong reasons.
Unable to arrive at intrinsic valuations that would justify investing in these companies at their current lofty market capitalizations, these analysts have looked for alternative ways to be able to make these “sells” into “buys.” As a consequence, the process has been biased and the practices that emerge from it are flawed.Intrinsic Valuation Can you modify intrinsic value models to value a user? The answer is yes and some analysts have jumped on to the bandwagon early.
In the process, though, they seem to forget some first principles that they would have heeded in conventional valuations.User immortality: The value of a user is the present value of the cash flows that you will generate from that user over his or her lifetime with your company.
To estimate that lifetime, you need to know customer renewal rates, and because many companies don’t reveal this information, some analysts value users on the assumption that they will stay users for the rest of their lives, or worse, for eternity.
That will overstate the value of a user.
Revenues as cash flows: The one number that analysts often can estimate easily is the revenue per user or subscriber, at least on an average basis.
In subscription-based models like Netflix, it comes from observing the price charged each subscriber, and in user-based models like Uber, it can be derived by dividing total revenues by the number of users.
Estimating how much was spent on servicing existing users is much more difficult at either of these companies.
Consequently, many user-based valuations consider revenues as cash flows, acting as if no costs are associated with servicing existing users and also that no taxes would have to be paid on the resulting income.
You can value a Netflix subscriber on the assumption that the annual subscription revenue of about $120/subscriber, in 2017, is the cash flow for the year but that will overvalue a subscriber.
New user magic: The value of a user-based company is the sum of the value of its existing users plus the value of any new users it will acquire over time.
That said, the value of a new user will be less than that of an existing user, for a simple reason.
It costs money to acquire new users.
Here again, the absence of concrete information about user acquisition costs leads some to ignore the costs altogether and give new users the same value as existing users, resulting in inflated values for companies that spend considerable amounts to acquire these new users.
Just as conventional companies can grow and destroy value by spending too much for that growth, user- based companies can add new users and destroy value in the process by spending too much on acquiring these new users.Corporate cost vacuums: After you have valued existing and new users and aggregated them, you have an extensive amount of mopping up to do, because user- based companies often have substantial costs that cannot be directly traced or charged to users.
Again, the absence of information on these costs leads some to ignore them when valuing companies, with predictable results (overvaluation).
Competitive Dynamics: We might have shifted from valuing companies to valuing users, but that does not mean that we can suspend the laws of economics and business.
A user-based company that faces intense competition, because it does not have significant barriers to entry, will struggle to create value, no matter how many users it adds, because the competition will keep a lid on its pricing power (and profit margins).
One of the perils of user-based valuation is that analysts sometimes get dazzled by the numbers (of users) and do not probe deeply enough into whether these users are exclusive or shared (Uber users can also be Lyft users) and how more conventional competitors for the user business (taxi cabs and mass transit still compete in the car service business) can keep pricing power in check.

 It is true that the process of valuing users and subscribers is still in its infancy and that we will have to make mistakes before we learn how to do it better.
That said, though, we should remember that just because we reframe the way we think about companies, we cannot abandon the rules that we used in conventional valuation.
Growth is not free, risk reduces value, and scaling up is hard to do.

 Relative Valuation If the intrinsic valuation of users is crudely practiced, at least at the moment, the pricing of users is even cruder, but even more widespread.
In the last decade, as user-based companies have been formed and capitalized, investors in these startups have faced a fundamental pricing problem.
Early in their life cycles, these companies are not only money-losing, but they do not have revenues of any substance, or physical assets.
Thus, you cannot use earnings multiples, book value multiples, or even revenue multiples to assess these companies.
Venture capitalists who are asked to invest in these companies therefore need a pricing metric or risk being shut out of the game.
It should come as no surprise then that many of them have latched on to the only number of magnitude at these companies, which is the number of users or subscribers, as the basis for pricing.

 In practical terms, this focus on users translates into a price per user, where the price of the company (the investor assessment of what it is worth) is divided by the number of users that the company is expected to have.
If that price is low, the company is considered cheap and if it is high, it is expensive.
Sensible venture capitalists recognize the danger in this approach, because it assumes that all users are created equal, when in reality the value per user should vary depending upon the user loyalty, user intensity, and revenue model of the company.
They follow up by probing the company for information that will allow them to make judgments on these user characteristics, before making a final determination.
Even among venture capitalists, though, there are some who abandon their responsibility for checking for user value, and price companies based upon just user numbers.

 When these companies go public early in their life cycle, the problems get worse for two reasons.
The first is that public market investors in the company do not have the capacity to extract information about users from the company that the venture capitalists did and thus are flying blind in regard to assessing user value.
The second is that the added liquidity in the market place makes this a pricing game, where even savvy investors think that they can use crude measures like price per user to decide when to buy a stock, notwithstanding the limits of the metric, because they plan to sell (hopefully at a higher price) and move on, before its limitations become obvious.

 The Light Side of Valuation To value or price a user right, you have to start with a framework for valuation or pricing that reflects first principles.
As we try to do that in this section, you will notice that we use information about users in the framework that is not currently public information.
Although that might strike you as impractical, we believe that tagging the information you need to value a user is the first step toward better information disclosure at these companies.

 Intrinsic Valuation At the risk of repeating a fundamental truth for the hundredth time in this book, the intrinsic value of an asset is a function of its expected cash flows, the expected growth in these cash flows, and the risk in these cash flows.
In the next three sections, we use this principle to develop a framework for valuing both existing and new users.
Specifically, we build up the value of a user-based company in three steps.
We first value an existing user, and use that value to value all existing users.
We then estimate the value added by a new user by netting out the cost of adding a new user, and in conjunction with estimates of the number of new users added in future periods, value all new users.
We put closure to the process by then attaching a value to corporate drag—that is, those expenses that are indispensable to business existence but unrelated to users—and netting that value out of the user value.Value of a user-based company = Value of Existing Users + Value of New Users−Value of Corporate Drag

 The Value of Existing Users If you are a user-/subscriber-based company with an existing user (or subscriber), that user/subscriber has value to you because you expect to generate cash flows from his or her interactions with you.
There are, broadly speaking, three ways (or revenue models) in which you can generate these cash flows:Subscription fees: The user or subscriber pays a fee, usually fixed, each period for using your service.
That fee can be the same for every subscriber, or tiered, with different fees for different levels of service, and generally will continue until the subscriber cancels the service.
Netflix, Microsoft’s Office 365, and Adobe’s Creative Cloud are all subscription fee-based models.
Advertising: With this model, users pay nothing for being on your service, but other businesses are attracted by your user base (its size and focus) to try to sell themproducts and services.
Facebook, Twitter, Snap, and Google are all user-based companies that generate their revenues from selling access to their user bases to other companies in the form of advertising or direct sales.
Transactions: With a transaction-based model, the user or subscriber transacts with or through you, and you generate profits from the transaction.
Uber, for instance, allows the download of its app for free but it generates revenues only when you use the app to call for a car service or delivery, sharing in the revenue from that transaction.

 As you can see, there are hybrid versions that draw on more than one of these models.
LinkedIn has both a subscription-based premium model for users who want to use its network more extensively, as well as a free model, where it generates revenues from online advertising.
Amazon Prime has an annual subscription fee that it charges members, but also generates revenues (and associated costs) when Prime members buy products on the Amazon portal.

 Whatever revenue model you use, the value of a user or a subscriber is the present value of the expected after-tax cash flows that you will generate from that user/subscriber over the period that you expect them to stay on your platform.
To derive this value, you need the following information:User life: Whether your users are individuals or businesses, the lifetime of that user to you will be finite, due to mortality.
In most cases, though, you will use a lifetime much shorter than the remaining life of a user, because your technology might have a more limited life.
Generally speaking, the more tied your product or service is to a specific technology, the shorter the user life will be.
User renewal rate: If your users renew 100% of the time, every user will stay on for his or her full lifetime, and you can count on the cash flows each year for that period.
If the renewal rate is less than 100%, the expected cash flows in future years have to reflect the survival likelihood for that customer.
For instance, if you have an annual renewal rate of 90%, the probability that a customer will be around in year 8 of a fifteen-year lifetime is only 43% (survival rate until year 9 = .98 = 0.43).
User cash flow (current): Your current cash flow per user is not just the revenue that you expect to generate from that user; it has to be netted out against the cost of servicing that user.
Thus, if Netflix generates $120/subscriber per year and spends $30 providing direct services to that subscriber, the base year cash flow for Netflix will be $90/subscriber, on a pre-tax basis, and perhaps only $72/subscriber, if it faces an effective tax rate of 20%.
With an advertising-based company, this is a more diffuse number to estimate but dividing your total advertising revenue in the most recent period by the number of users you had during the period will be your starting point for revenues, though you will still need to net out costs.
Growth in per-user cash flow: After you have acquired a user, you might be able to sell that user other products and services in the future, leading to growth in the per-user revenues, and if some of your service costs are fixed, your operating profits per user will grow even more quickly.
That growth, though, will depend on your business model.
For Netflix, with its annual subscription-based model, there are limits to how much you can raise that subscription on an annual basis.
For Amazon Prime, there is amuch larger potential for growth, because a Prime member can be targeted with new products and services.
One outgrowth from Amazon’s acquisition of Whole Foods in 2017, for instance, is that the company can offer prepared meals to its Prime members as an added product.
Risk in cash flow: Because the risk of losing a user is already built into the expected cash flow, the primary risk here comes from both variations in renewal rates over time and from how much cash flow you can generate from each user.
Again, your revenue model matters, with subscription-based models delivering more predictable revenues than transaction-based models, and the discount rates you use to value the cash flows have to reflect risk differences.Figure 17.1 brings together all of these variables into a picture.Figure 17.1 The Value of an Existing User

 As you look at the information that you will need to derive this value, you are probably also recognizing that the information disclosures that we have from user-based companies now are seriously lacking.
While we will try to patch our way to valuing a user in the example at the end of this section, we believe that the path forward has to include more complete user- related information from companies.

 The Value of New Users If you are a user-based company, your value comes not only from existing users but from the new users that you hope to add on.
The value of a new user is driven by many of the same variables that drive the value of an existing user (user cash flow, growth, and risk) but two additional parameters enter the equation:As with the value of an existing user, you can capture the drivers of new user value in a picture (as we have attempted to, in Figure 17.2):Figure 17.2 The Value of a New User

 This picture provides insight into different business models that user-based companies can adopt.
Holding all else constant, you would like to be able to have a business model where an existing user has a very high value and it costs you little to add new users.
In the real world, those two phenomena generally don’t go together, because the features of the business that allow you to add new users at low cost usually allow your competitors to do the same.
As a consequence, they can go after your customers, causing renewal rates and cash flows per user to drop, and with them, the value per existing user.
To succeed when both the value per user and the cost per acquiring new users are low, you need a model with lots of users.
Conversely, you could live with an exclusive user model, where you have relatively few users that deliver high value per user and the cost of acquiring users is very high as well, though much of your growth will then have to come from selling more to your existing users.
There is one combination, though, that is deadly for value and that is if you have existing users of low value but your costs of acquiring new users is high.
Table 17.16 captures the combinations of existing user value and cost per user and the resulting business consequences.Table 17.16 Existing User Value/New User Acquisition Costs

 This framework is useful in understanding what makes some user-based companies stand apart as stars.
These companies draw on their competitive advantages, which include networking benefits (where it gets cheaper to acquire new customers as you get larger) and big data (which can be used to learn more about users and perhaps customize offerings to get them to buy more) to lower their customer acquisition costs while keeping customer value high.
They remain the exception, not the rule.

 The Corporate Drag One final component of value in user-based companies has to be brought into the valuation for it to be complete.
Earlier in this chapter, when discussing sum-of-the-parts valuation, we noted that corporate G&A costs, which are the costs of centralized corporate services that all the parts of the company can benefit from, have to be valued and brought in for the final valuation to reflect a true value for the company.
In the same vein, when valuing user-based companies, many expenses are either unrelated to servicing existing users or cannot be directly tied to acquiring new users that have to be incorporated in the valuation.
Take Netflix, for instance, where an existing subscriber costs little to service, and delivers $120 in annual revenues.
The company spent $8 billion in 2017 acquiring and making new content, and this new content is what keeps existing subscribers and attracts new subscribers.
At the same time, it is almost impossible to determine how much of this spending is for existing customers and how much is to get growth in the subscriber base.
Consequently, you might choose to ignore this cost when valuing existing and new users at Netflix, but you cannot ignore it if your intent is to invest in the company.

 To value these non–user-related costs, or corporate drag as we prefer to term it, we first have to determine how much of the existing costs go into this category.
The only way to make sure that you are not missing big chunks of costs is to work backward from the total costs.
Thus, whatever costs you have not assigned to existing users and new users in your model will have to go into the corporate drag category.
To provide a simple illustration, assume that you are valuing users at a company that has 10 million existing users and that added 2 million new users last year.
Assume also that you have estimated a cost of $25/year for servicing existing users and $100 for acquiring a new user.
Finally, assume that the company had total expenses of $750 million in the most recent year.
The corporate drag is estimated as follows:Cost of servicing existing users = $25 × 10 million = $250 millionCost of adding new users = $100 × 2 million = $200 millionTotal costs for the company for period = $750 millionCorporate drag = $750 − $250 − $200 = $300 million

 After you estimate the corporate drag, valuing it requires you to make two other assumptions.
The first is the expected growth rate in that cost, and that growth rate will depend on how connected the cost is to the user base.
In general, there will be economies of scale that will cause these expenses to grow at a lower rate, at least at healthy firms, than the growth rate in revenues from existing and new users.
The second is the uncertainty about these costs, which will depend on the cost type and structure.
Netflix, for instance, enters into long-term contracts with studios, where its costs in future years are contractually set, effectively making them more certain and causing a greater drag on value.
Figure 17.3 captures the corporate drag effect on value.Figure 17.3 The Cost of Corporate Drag

 There are some interesting implications that come from this component of value as well.
If the corporate drag cost is mostly fixed and a large portion of total expenses, thus making for economies of scale, user-based companies can both benefit and be hurt.
They can benefit because growth will create a much bigger boost in earnings and value, but they can be hurt because they are riskier.
If users start to spend less or new user growth slackens, the high fixed costs at these companies can cause implosions and put survival at risk.In 2017, Uber, the ride-sharing company, had succeeded in disrupting the car service business around the globe.
With 40 million riders/users and operating in more than 180 countries, Uber had gross billings of $20 billion in the twelve months leading into June 2017, translating into revenue of $6.5 billion for the period; its business model is built around connecting owner-operated cars with Uber users who need car service and keeping a share (20%, in 2017) of the gross fare.
However, the company still faced multiple challenges, some self-inflicted, and some from outside forces.
First, its business model, while successful at delivering rider and revenue growth, was not profitable, and the company reported a loss of $2.8 billion during the period.
Second, the company was fighting battles against regulators and courts in multiple cities on many fronts, creating not just legal costs but uncertainties about future revenues and profits.
Third, the company’s board of directors and top management was in turmoil, with the CEO, Travis Kalatnick, taking a (forced) leave of absence.
We will value Uber, first using an aggregated valuation model, and then take another try, valuing its users.Notwithstanding its outsized profile, Uber is still a young company and in keeping with our argument in Chapter 9, its value has to be built around a story.
To value Uber in June 2017, we built the valuation around the following story lines:The company will grow both globally and across the logistics business: The company will continue to be able to grow its revenues as it expands from car service into delivery and moving businesses, attracts new users into the business, and increasingly looks overseas.
We see gross billings growing to $215 billion by year 10, representing a market share of 40% of its expanded market.
With increased competition: As it grows, it will feel pressure from competitors who will try to hire away its service providers, causing the share of gross billings to drop to 15% by year 10, leading to revenues of $32.2 billion in year 10.
And gradual improvement in margins: The company’s operating margins will turn positive as economies of scale kick in, about five years in, but competition and regulatory costs will result in a target operating margin of 20% by year 10.
(The after- tax operating income in year 10, with a 30% tax rate, will be $4.514 billion.) With increased capital intensity: The company’s business model, which has historically been “capital-light,” largely because Uber does not buy or own cars, will become more capital intensive as Uber invests in electric cars and infrastructure to compete with Google and other players entering the self-driving car business.
We assume that every dollar invested in the business will generate $3 in revenues, leading to significant reinvestment in 2017–2020, as the company grows.
And substantial risk: Uber remains a risky company and we will give it a cost of capital of 10%, set at the 75th percentile of all publicly traded companies in the United States.
Because the company is still money-losing and dependent on external capital to make it through the next five years of negative cash flows, we will assume that there remains a 5% chance of failure.Figure 17.4 The Value of Uber (Aggregated)The value of Uber, based upon our story for the company, is $36 billion.
Note that the operating assets are worth $25 billion and the additional $11 billion come from two other investments: a share of Didi Chuxing, the Chinese ride-sharing company, worth $6 billion, and $5 billion in cash, from their latest capital round.The pushback that we received on the Uber aggregated valuation was that Uber was a user-based company and that valuing it on an aggregated basis was missing that link to value.
Consequently, we valued Uber using the user valuation framework developed earlier this chapter.1.
Deconstructing the Financial Statements.
Uber is a privately held company and its financial disclosures take the form of leaks that selectively reveal information about the company.
It is therefore a particular challenge to estimate how much the company is spending and for what purpose.
Starting with the crude information that we had on gross billings ($20 billion in the most recent 12 months), the $6.5 billion in revenues and $2.8 billion in operating loss, and the number of users (40 million at the time of the valuation, up 16 million from the prior year), we tried to back out the numbers that we need for valuing users, as shown in Figure 17.5.Figure 17.5 Deconstructing Uber’s FinancialsAlthough this might seem like grasping for straws, we started with the total operating expense of $9.3 billion (obtained by adding back operating losses to revenues) and used the contribution margin that the company also leaked (10.10% of revenues in its existing markets) to estimate how much of the expenses were for servicing existing users (amounting to $4.48 billion).
After estimating that the corporate drag was $1 billion, we assumed that the remaining costs ($3.82 billion) were spent acquiring new users (16 million during the year) to estimate the cost per new user to be $238.75.Figure 17.6 Value of Existing Users at Uber in MillionsBased on our assumptions, the value of an existing user at Uber is $449.17, which when multiplied by 40 million users yields a total value of $17,967 million.Figure 17.7 Value of New Users at Uber ($ Millions)The value per new user is $210.39 currently ($449.17–$238.75), and it will grow at the inflation rate over time, leading to a collective value for new users of $23,858 million.

The Corporate Drag.
To value the corporate drag, we start with the initial cost of $1 billion and assume that it will grow at 5% a year, lower than the growth rate in users and revenues, largely because most of these costs are likely to be fixed costs.
Figure 17.8 shows the resulting value of reverting to a 10% cost of capital.Figure 17.8 The Corporate Drag at UberThe value of corporate drag is $11,148 million, and this reduces the overall value of the company.Adding cash ($5 billion) and the value of the Didi Chuxing holding ($6 billion) yields a value of $41.7 billion for the company, a little higher than the aggregated value that we estimated earlier.

 Relative Valuation One of the side benefits of going through the process of valuing a user is that it provides a framework for assessing why user values should vary across companies.
It can therefore be an invaluable addendum to a pricing analysis, where instead of comparing price per user across companies, you control for differences across companies, using proxies to measure the variables that should cause the pricing to vary.
The following table summarizes the variables, largely based on the value framework in the last section, and what you could use to measure these variables.
(Note that the Price/User in this table refers to the market capitalization of the company divided by the number of users and is a pricing metric.)

 Using this table, you can quickly see why the price per user at Facebook will be substantially higher than the price per user at Twitter, as the former has more loyal and intense users, and why the price per user at Blue Apron plummeted when Amazon acquired Whole Foods, as investors reassessed user growth and costs at the company, with Amazon as a competitor.

 Here again, you might take issue with the fact that doing pricing right requires you to have information on user characteristics that are either not provided or provided sporadically.
Our perspective is that, if you are an analyst or investor, you should be questioning managers on these parameters, and if you are a regulator or an accounting rule writer, this type of information should be part of every user-based company’s public disclosure.

 Conclusion In this chapter, we turned our attention to what we term disaggregated valuation, where we value companies in pieces.
We started with multinational, multibusiness companies and argued that companies that spread their tentacles across multiple businesses and many parts of the globe are difficult to value, because their cash flows from each business or region can have very different risk and growth characteristics.
This chapter looked at two ways we can approach the valuation of these.
The first is to value the company as a whole, using the weighted averages of risk parameters to estimate discount rates, which we then use to discount consolidated cash flows for the firm.
The dangers here are that the weights will change over time, and as they do, so will the firm’s fundamentals.
The second way is to value the cash flow streams separately, using different risk measures and growth rates for each stream.
Thus, emerging-market and risky business cash flows will be discounted at higher rates than developed-market and safer business cash flows.
The aggregated value of the different businesses should yield a better estimate of the overall company’s value.

 When we use relative valuation to value these companies, we run into the same valuation issues.
Again, we can try to value the consolidated firm, but finding companies that are similar in business mix is almost impossible.
For that reason, it makes sense to expand our definition of comparable firms to include firms that might not be similar to the multibusiness firm that we are valuing, and to control for differences in valuation fundamentals—risk, cash flow, and growth.
Alternatively, we can try to find comparable firms within each business and then use the information on how the market is pricing these companies to value the pieces that make up the larger firm.
No matter what approach we use, we will be faced with more complexity and information gaps with multibusiness companies than with single- business, independent companies.
We have to determine whether this complexity exposes us to more risk and, if so, how we will incorporate that concern into value.

 In the last part of the chapter, we looked at user-, subscriber-, and customer-based companies where the focus in both valuation and pricing has been on the users.
We argued that intrinsic valuation models can be adapted to value both existing and new users in a company, and through those values, you can extract the value of a user-based company.
We then used the insights from those valuation models to examine how we can price users at companies, listing the variables that might cause this price to vary across companies.___________________________ 1.
Firms with large cash balances are attractive targets, because the cash balance can be used to offset some of the cost ofinformation that reduces its value, there should be another complex company where the information that comes out increases value.
In a diversified portfolio, these effects should average out to zero.

 This might sound like heresy in a book on valuation, but some investments cannot be valued.
It is not because too much uncertainty exists, an excuse used by some who choose not to value young or emerging market companies, or because there is not not enough information, because you can always make estimates to fill in the gaps.
It is because some investments are not cash flow-generating assets, but are instead commodities, currencies, or collectibles.
If you are puzzled about the distinction, we delineate the differences in this chapter, after revisiting a discussion that we started in Chapter 3 about the difference between value and price.
We then talk about the choices we have, when called upon to put a number on a collectible or currency.

 In Chapter 4, we argue that the value and pricing processes can yield different numbers for the same asset, with the value process being driven by fundamentals, and the pricing process by demand and supply.
We have stayed true to that differentiation through the chapters so far by dividing the discussion of the both the dark side of valuation and its remedies into intrinsic valuation and relative valuation (pricing) sections.

 The determinants of value are simple, although not always not easy to estimate.
Whether you are valuing start-up businesses, emerging market firms, or commodity companies, the values are driven by expected cash flows, growth, and risk.
Although a discounted cash flow valuation is often the tool that we used to give form to these fundamentals, in the form of cash flows, growth rates in these cash flows, and discount rates, it is not the only pathway to intrinsic value.

 The determinants of price are demand and supply, and while fundamentals do affect both, clearly both mood and momentum are also strong forces in pricing.
These “animal spirits,” as behavioral economists might tag them, can not only cause price to diverge from value, but also require different tools to be used to assess the right pricing for an asset.
With many assets and businesses, pricing an asset usually involves standardizing a price (a multiple), finding similar or comparable assets that are already priced in the marketplace, and controlling for differences.

 If you believe that markets make mistakes, but that these mistakes are random and unrelated to any observable variables, you are assuming that the value and pricing processes yield the same result on average.
In short, you are a believer in efficient markets.
Note that you can believe that investors are irrational and still believe that markets are efficient, if you also believe that irrationality cuts in both directions, leading some to buy when they should not and others to sell when they should not, leading to a canceling out of irrationalities.

 If you don’t buy into the notion that markets are efficient, you also believe that the value and the pricing processes can yield different numbers and that you can detect both the direction and magnitude of the difference; that is, whether the price of an asset is greater or less than its value and by how much, with your methods, metrics, and models.
In fact, as we argue in the next section, views on price and value dynamics are what separate traders from investors and lead to different investment philosophies.

 Investing versus Trading If you can both value and price assets, which number should drive your investment decisions? Rather than answer with absolutes, we would argue that the choice depends on a multitude of factors, including how much faith you have in your estimate of value and that markets correct to that value, and what your time horizon is.
If you are putting your money at play based on your assessment, you can play two games, the value game and the pricing game, and that choice, in turn, determines whether you should think of yourself as an investor or a trader.

 The Value Game versus the Pricing Game The value game is the one that many old-time value investors will recognize as the core lesson taught by Ben Graham and his many disciples.
In the value game, you assess a value to an asset and compare that value to the price.
If the value is higher than the price, you buy the asset and wait for the market to correct its mistake.
In the words of Warren Buffet, you are taking advantage of Mr.
Market’s mood swings to make money off the market.
To play the value game for profit, you not only have to be able to value assets, but you also have to have enough faith in that value to hold on, even if the market moves in the opposite direction, secure that if you wait long enough, it will correct its mistakes.

 The pricing game is a simpler one.
You price an asset relative to how the market is pricing similar assets, and buy an asset if it is underpriced.
You wait for the pricing divergence to disappear and make your money from the correction.
Note that you are agnostic about whether fundamentals matter or should even come into place, using them only if you believe that they will help you better price an asset.
To play the pricing game well, you have to be able to not only assess the metrics that the market is using to price an asset, but also be an early detector of mood and momentum shifts that cause pricing to switch directions.
Unlike the value game, which usually requires long time horizons, the pricing game can be played in seconds, minutes, and hours, though some pricing games exist that are long-term.

 Investing versus Trading Extending the distinction, we will call those who play the value game investors and those who play the pricing game traders.
Note that no judgment is being passed in these terms.
Nothing is inherently nobler about investing than trading, notwithstanding the biases we might bring to the process.
Both are driven by the desire to make money or by greed, and success at both is measured eventually by how much money is made.
They might require different time horizons, tools, and skills to succeed at, and we have tried to capture those differences in Table 18.1.Table 18.1 The Value Game (Investing) versus the Pricing Game (Trading)Can be very short-term (minutes) to somewhat long- term (months).Generally long-term, to give markets time to correct mistakes.Be able to gauge market mood/momentum shifts earlierBe able to value assets, given uncertainty.As you can see, your choice on whether to be an investor or a trader will depend on who you are, what makes you tick, and what you believe your differential advantages are.

 The Dark Side You can be a good investor or a good trader, but the dark side beckons when you are delusional or deceptive about the game you are playing.
Many market participants manage to delude themselves into thinking that they are playing a game that is different from the one that they actually are.
Thus, we see portfolio managers, who call themselves value investors and swear by the precepts of value, who then proceed to load up their portfolios with momentum stocks that reflects their trading biases.
We also see analysts who start off with fundamental analysis and discounted cash flow models to value companies but then reframe their decisions as pricing decisions, using multiples and comparable firms.The dark side also beckons when you become righteous in your choice of value or pricing game, convinced that those who don’t make the same choice are misguided, shallow, or irrational.
This is particularly true among

 some old-time value investors, who are quick to consign anyone who is not in their camp into investment hell, destined to lose money over time.
They lecture others about the insanity of paying high multiples of earnings, book value, and revenues and avoid investing in large swaths of the market that look overvalued to them, using their metrics.
Their contempt for those who play the pricing game carries over into the labels (speculators, short-term traders) that they attach to them and their unwillingness to even consider the drivers of price.

 The Light Side The light side requires honesty.
If you are playing the pricing game, you should play it well using pricing tools, where you price stocks based upon multiples and comparable firms and use charts to detect shifts in moods and momentum.
If you are playing the value game, you should stop worrying about day-to-day movements in stock prices and trying to explain them using fundamentals.
In addition, you should not try to reason with traders and markets to get them to see the errors of their ways.

 The light side also requires humility.
Recognizing that others who have different skill sets, views on markets, and time horizons will make different choices will give you perspective.
Thus, when the price of a stock drops 20 percent on a seemingly minor news story, you will find it easier, as a value player, to understand, if you acknowledge that incremental information can lead to large pricing changes.
In fact, understanding what traders look at (multiples and charts) and how they act can make you a better value investor by giving you insights on how markets correct mistakes.
If you are a trader, you can gain from understanding the fundamentals that drive value, even if you do not use them in your trading decisions, because they might yield measures that help you predict mood and momentum shifts.

 If you can both value and price an asset, what should you do if you are asked to put a number on it? That is a question that we face almost daily in acquisitions, when we have to value target companies, in accounting, as fair value standards displace book value, and in legal settings, where courts are called upon to settle disputes about the numbers attached to assets.
Many of the struggles that we face arise because of confusion about whether we are valuing or pricing assets.

 Job Description In some cases, your job description will itself give you an indication of whether you should be valuing or pricing assets.
To illustrate, consider equity research analysts, whether they be on the buy side (working for portfolio managers) or on the sell side (providing their research to their clients).
Their jobs are usually sector-focused, with an analyst being given the responsibility of covering the companies in the software, banking, or steel sector, and then being asked to make judgments on which of the companies are buys, sells, or holds.
The very nature of that assignment indicates that the analysts are being asked to price companies relative to each other, and not relative to intrinsic value, and that underpriced (not undervalued) companies will become the buys and overpriced (not overvalued) companies will be the sells.
Equity research analysts who misunderstand their mission and use intrinsic valuation to conclude that everything in their sectors is under- or overvalued will find themselves unemployed sooner rather than later.

 Cui Bono? In still other cases, self-interest will drive your choice of valuing or pricing an asset.
If you are an intermediary appraising a company for a transaction, as is the case when bankers assess target companies for M&A transactions or young tech companies for initial public offerings, your job and your fees are tied to getting transactions done.
Consequently, you will be pricing (not valuing) target companies and IPOs, because transactions occur at prices and not your assessments of intrinsic value.
I am sure that there are some bankers with long-term client relationships who might be willing to provide value advice that leads to a transaction not being done, but they tend to be the exception rather than the rule.

 How Are You Judged? One final component determines whether you will be drawn more strongly to the pricing or to the value side, and that is how you are judged and measured.
If, as is the case in much of portfolio management, you are judged relative to other portfolio managers, often categorized by the types of companies invested in, you will be more inclined to price assets, because pricing is relative valuation.
If one of the dangers in pricing is that momentum can shift and entire sectors or even the market can be marked down, you might still be tagged as a success if your holdings are less overpriced than everyone else’s holdings.

 The Dark Side For decades, in valuation classes and books, as well as in the testing for professional standards, value approaches (discounted cash flow valuations and financial ratios) have been elevated above pricing approaches.
In fact, many valuation books either look at using pricing multiples (like PE ratios and EV to EBITDA multiples) in passing or completely ignore them.
As a consequence, analysts and appraisers are often wary about admitting to colleagues and clients that they do pricing, not valuation, and feel the urge to cover up their pricing tracks.Accounting rule makers and legal arbitrators have bought into the mythology and demand to see intrinsic valuation backing for numbers that are clearly pricing numbers.
We would argue that fair value accounting

 should really be called fair price accounting because the mission is to estimate what investors will pay for an asset, not what its worth.
FAS 157, US accounting’s core rule on fair value, defines the fair value in terms of an exchange price, which is defined in the rule as “the price in an orderly transaction between market participants to sell the asset or transfer the liability in the market in which the reporting entity would transact for the asset or liability.” That is clearly a pricing mission and it follows that accountants should be required to use pricing tools (multiples and comparable firms) to back them up.
Instead, accounting rule writers have burdened fair value accountants with the requirement that they create discounted cash flow valuations to back their pricing.

 In the legal arena, there is even more confusion, partly because courts have been unclear about whether value or price is being contested.
In most legal tussles, whether it be on the price paid for a target company in an acquisition or whether minority shareholders are being treated fairly, we would argue that fair price is what is being debated, not a fair value.
Here again, though, expert witnesses for both sides present elaborate discounted cash flow models to justify their pricing conclusions.

 Many analysts try to split the difference by mixing together their value and pricing numbers to deliver averaged numbers that are neither price nor value.
Thus, seeing an IPO analyst report that his or her DCF value for a company is $12 and that the multiple-based value is $16, and to then split the difference and estimate a value of $14 for the company, is not uncommon.
Averaging value and price gives you appraisal mush, because what you get as your final estimates is neither a good valuation nor a good pricing.The Light Side After you accept the proposition that you can either price or value an asset and that neither approach is inherently superior or inferior, the road to doing either well lies in clarity and transparency.should use the tools that are best suited to our mission, pricing tools when pricing companies and intrinsic valuation models when we are valuing businesses, and use those tools well.
Be transparent in your working: After we have valued or priced a business or asset, we should be transparent about how we got to the number for two reasons.
First, if a transaction or judgment is to be based on that number, it should not come from an opaque process, a black box that only the analyst has access to.
Thus, if we have valued a company, the inputs to the valuation should be explained and presented in such a way that users can not only see where the numbers came from but also the story that ties them together.
If we have priced a company, we should not only explain why we chose the multiple that we used but how we came up with the comparable firms.
Second, the essence of both value and price is that different people looking at the same asset can come to very different judgments about it, and transparency allows for a more productive debate about the assumptions that underlie value and price.
Be aware of the limitations: Whether you price or value businesses or assets, you are not only making assumptions about how the market works, but you should also be clear about the limits.
When valuing businesses or assets, you are assuming that not only are your assumptions about cash flows, growth, and risk reasonable, but that the price of risk in markets (in the form of equity risk premiums and default spreads) are stable.
If a market crisis causes the price of risk to change significantly, your value will change as well.
When pricing assets, you are making a specific judgment about how your company is being priced, given how the market is pricing similar companies.
Put differently, if the market is overpricing similar companies, you will also be overpricing your company.
An asset can be underpriced and overvalued or overpriced and undervalued at the same time.The bottom line is that you can do either a good valuation or a good pricing, but trying to do both or come up with a number that reconciles the two is a recipe for confusion.

 In this section, we delineate investments into four categories to draw a sharper distinction between value and pricing.
The first are cash flow– generating assets, which include everything from stand alone assets like trademarks to small, privately owned businesses, to investments (stock or bond) in publicly traded companies.
The second are commodities, which derive their value from their usage in a production process that generates a useful product or service that businesses or consumers need and will pay for.
The third are currencies, which are used to denominate your cash flows and can include everything from fiat currencies to gold and crypto currencies.
The final grouping is for collectibles, whose owners derive value from their aesthetic value or for emotional reasons.
We will argue that assets can be valued and priced, that commodities are mostly priced, and that currencies and collectibles can only be priced.

 Cash Flow–Generating Assets An asset generates or is expected to generate cash flows in the future.
A business that you own is definitely an asset, as is a claim on the cash flows on that business.
Those claims can be either contractually set (bonds or debt), residual (equity or stock), or even contingent (options).
What assets share in common is that these cash flows can be valued, and assets with high cash flows and less risk should be valued more than assets with lower cash flows and more risk.

 At the same time, assets can also be priced relative to each other by scaling the price that you pay to a common metric.
With stocks, this takes the form of comparing pricing multiples (PE ratio, EV/EBITDA, price to book, or value/sales) across similar companies to form pricing judgments of which stocks are cheap and which ones are expensive.

 Most of the valuations that we have presented in this book have been of companies or businesses, but it is worth remembering that the techniques used here can be used to value individual assets or projects.
Thus, you can apply discounted cash flow models to value a physical asset, a trademark, or a license, and any project analysis is really a valuation exercise.

 Valuing an Asset The basis of valuation for valuing an individual asset or project is identical to the basis for valuing an entire company or business.
The value of an asset or project is a function of its cash flows, risk, and growth, and can be written as follows (for an asset with a life of n years):That said, there some practical considerations that can make project or asset valuation a little different from valuing entire companies.No market pricing: If you are dependent on market pricing for your risk parameters (like betas), you will find yourself quickly in a dead end when valuing projects or individual assets.
Unlike publicly traded companies, where the shares of the company get traded in a market place, yielding prices, assets and projects do not.
Financing mix: In Chapter 2, we argued that the debt and equity mixes used to compute the cost of capital should be estimated in market value terms.
Again, while this is easy to do with publicly traded companies, it is not easy to do with projects or individual assets.
To add to this problem, companies can often choose to fund an individual project entirely with debt or entirely with equity, depending on its sequence in the investment cycle.
Incremental versus allocated items: When assessing cash flows for projects or individual assets that are owned by businesses, you might find yourself looking at financial statements that reflect corporate judgments of how much of a centralized or corporate cost should be borne by the asset.
These allocated costs can alter the bottom line (earnings and cash flows) significantly.
Taxes: The income generated by projects or individual assets usually does not get taxed at that level.
Instead, it becomes part of a consolidated business income, which is taxed.
There are two reasons why this can matter.
First, a money-losing company has to wait until it has income to claim the tax savings from its losses; that is why we carried net operating losses forward in prior chapters to offset against income in future years.
A money-losing project might be able to generate tax benefits for the company if the latter has positiveearnings on the rest of its operations.
Second, while you can use an effective tax rate in valuing an entire company, a project’s cash flows may be taxed at the margin, requiring the use of a marginal tax rate.None of these issues are insurmountable and we have, in fact, confronted and solved some of them in earlier examples in the book, but it is worth revisiting both the dark and the light side, specifically in the context of project or asset valuation.

 The Dark Side One reason that bad practices find their way into project or asset valuation is because they are often taught and treated as different from valuation, usually becoming part of capital budgeting in a corporate finance context.
But capital budgeting, to the extent that it is built around net present value, is just discounted cash flow valuation in a different setting, and what comprises bad practices in valuation should also be bad practices in project/asset analysis.One size fits all for risk: Perhaps the most common mistake that is made in project analysis is the use of a company-wide cost of capital as the discount rate for all projects taken by the company in question.
We argued that this was bad practice, when valuing multi-business companies in Chapter 17, and it remains a bad practice at the project level, with predictable consequences.
A company with projects with different risk profiles that insists on using a single corporate cost of capital for all of them will overinvest in risky projects and underinvest in safe projects.
Over time, it will not only become a riskier company, but a riskier company with buyer’s remorse, with lots of value-destroying, risky projects in its portfolio.
Project-specific financing: In many cases, companies are explicit not only about how much they will borrow for a new project and at what rate, but also about how they plan to pay off the debt over the project’s lifetime.
For many analysts, this seems like an easy solution to the debt ratio problem, with many using the project debt mix to compute the cost of capital.
In fact, analysts who want to exercise their analytical muscles go further and often compute debt ratios over time, as the debt gets paid off.
There are two problems with thisapproach.
The first is that the debt ratio, even if given for a project, is in book value terms.
It is stated as a percent of the cost of the project investment and not its value and that problem will get magnified in future years as the project ages and debt gets paid down.
The second is that the amount of debt that a company uses to finance an individual project or asset usually has little to do with the debt capacity of that project or asset and has more to do with the company’s debt standing.
Thus, a company that has significant excess debt capacity can choose to fund a project entirely with debt and using that debt ratio (100 percent debt, no equity) will give it a very low cost of capital (equal to the after-tax cost of debt).
Valuing the project with this low cost of capital will overvalue it, just as you will undervalue a later project that might be funded entirely with equity.
Trust in accounting earnings: The process of getting from earnings to cash flows is no different for an individual asset or project than it is for a company.
You start with accounting earnings, add back noncash expenses (like depreciation and amortization) and subtract out capital expenditures and change in working capital.
The difference is that the earnings for a project or individual asset often are after allocated expenses, some of which might be attributable to the project and some of which might not.
Analysts who estimate cash flows for projects based on stated accounting earnings will be misestimating those cash flows, underestimating them when projects are being allocated costs that are not attributable to them, and overestimating them when some project costs are being missed.
Post-analysis garnishing: In earlier chapters, we pointed to the use of buzzwords to justify both more or less than estimated value.
In acquisitions, we noted that analysts use synergy and control as justifications for premiums on target company valuations and in private company valuation, and that analysts use illiquidity as a rationale for discounting value.
In the context of project or asset valuation, this process continues with analysts arguing that a project with a negative net present value should be accepted for strategic reasons or that an asset has extra value because of its brand name, with no attempt made to enumerate either benefit.

 When companies adopt bad practices in project assessment, we deal with the consequences when we value these companies.
The systematic biases created by using company-wide discount rates, project-specific financing, and accounting earnings at the project level translate into bad projects; that is, projects that earn less than the cost of capital, and value destruction at the company level.The Light Side The following corrections needed for the dark side practices should be familiar, because we have used them before, albeit in different contexts:Look at project risk, not company risk: At the risk of repeating a lesson that we have emphasized through this book, the discount rate used to value a set of cash flows should reflect the risk in those cash flows and not the risk of the entity looking at those cash flows.
Thus, discounting the cash flows on a risky project using the discount rate of the safe company looking at these cash flows makes no sense.
Although starting from scratch and assessing the risk of each project or asset might not be practical, we can classify assets into risk groups and at least assess different discount rates for each grouping.
Thus, a multibusiness, multinational company like United Technologies should, at the minimum, have different costs of capital for its different divisions and geographies.
The cost of capital for a project in Asia for its Sikorsky (aircraft) division should be very different, even in U.S.
dollar terms, from the cost of capital for a project in Europe for its Otis (elevator) business.
To do this, though, you have to be willing to abandon the practice of using a single regression beta for a company, using business-based or bottom-up betas [which is the approach that we have used all through this book] instead, and to estimate equity risk premiums that vary across countries.
On financing mix, look at project debt capacity: Taking the mix of debt and equity used for a project as the mix in computing cost of capital is never good practice, and it is especially dangerous when it is book value–based and projects do not stand alone.
For a company with a portfolio of projects in a single business, as is the case with a retail company with a multitude of stores, we recommend using a company-wide debt ratio based on market values as the debt ratio foreach project, no matter how it is funded.
This eliminates the subsidization that occurs when project-specific debt ratios are used, where equity-funded projects subsidize debt-funded ones.
For a company like United Technologies (which we valued in Chapter 17) that has portfolios of projects in multiple businesses, with different debt capacities, we suggest using the division-specific debt ratio for all projects in that division.
Although it is true that companies pay down debt associated with individual projects, we recommend continuing to use the same debt ratio over time, because that debt that is paid down will be replaced with new debt on other projects.
Only for stand-alone projects that have the capacity to carry their own debt do we recommend using project-specific debt ratios and adjusting them over time for debt repayment.1 Incremental cash flows: A simple rule in decision making is that decisions should be based on incremental and forward-looking cash flows.
In the context of valuing projects and assets, this requires us to not take project earnings, at least as reported by accountants, at face value and instead go through the financial statements, line item by line item, asking two questions.
First, what will happen to this line item if we take this project? Second, what will happen to this line item if we do not take this project? If the answer is the same to both questions, that line item is not incremental and should not be part of your analysis.
To illustrate this, consider two examples.
In the first, assume that you are looking at a line item for test market expenses of $50 million that have already been incurred for a project under consideration.
Because that expense will be unchanged whether you take this project or not, it should be ignored; this is, of course, a classic sunk cost.
In the second, consider a line item for allocated General and Administrative (G&A) costs of $50 million but assume that $40 million of these expenses are fixed expenses that would just be allocated elsewhere in the company if this project is not taken.
You should consider only the $10 million in incremental G&A costs in the project analysis.
No project garnishing: As with synergy, control, and liquidity, the best practice in project analysis is to convert hitherto uncaptured benefits, be they in the form of strategic payoffs or in brand name, inthe cash flows.
With strategic benefits, this might require bringing in some of the option pricing approaches that we introduced in earlier chapters, and with brand name, the profit margins used in the analysis might have to be revisited.Analyzing individual projects well and making the right judgments on them is key to building valuable businesses.
As you can see, the right practices to adopt in capital budgeting mirror the right practices to use in valuation.
If you master one, you should be able to do the other.

 Commodities A commodity derives its value from its use as raw material to meet a fundamental need, either among consumers or businesses.
Although that value can be estimated by looking at the demand for and supply of the commodity, long lag and lead times in both make that valuation process much more difficult than for an asset.
Consequently, commodities tend to be priced for the most part, though pricing practices can vary across different types of commodities.

 Pricing Commodities Three broad approaches exist for pricing commodities.
In the first, you price a commodity by looking at its own price history.
In the second, you price a commodity relative to another commodity that it is linked to, either because of its usage or its production details.
In the third, you try to tie a commodity’s price to its fundamentals by bringing proxies for demand and supply of the commodity into the assessmentRelative to other commodities: Sometimes, commodities are paired off against other commodities and the ratio of prices across the commodities is used to make judgments on whether one commodity is being mispriced relative to the other, given past history.
Thus, oil and natural gas, which compete to serve home energy needs, have a history of moving together.
So do corn and soybean prices, partly because farmers can switch from one crop to the other if one is priced too high relative to the other.
Here, you are assuming that the historical price relationships between the commodities in question will continue to hold in the future and that mean reversion will cause price adjustments.
Based upon fundamentals: In some cases, you will find an economist or a commodity expert try to price a commodity by trying to forecast long-term trends in supply and demand of that commodity.
Practically, this will require identifying the fundamental variables that you believe capture commodity demand and supply and finding a way to tie commodity prices to these variables, usually through regressions or other statistical techniques.
You could tie oil prices to oil reserves/production and energy consumption around the world and perhaps build a model for predicting the former, given your views on the latter.
It was an expectation of growth in demand for oil from the expanding Chinese auto market that led some forecasters in 2010 to predict that oil prices would rise to $200 a barrel.It is worth noting that, while forecasting commodity prices remains difficult, the payoff from doing it right is so high that people will continue to do so.

 The Dark Side Commodity price forecasting is practiced widely, but it is not practiced very well.
Commodity companies often make their acquisition and investment decisions based on their expectations about future prices.
Investors often base their decisions on when to invest in commodity companies, and in which ones, on forecasts of commodity prices.
That said, though, commodity price forecasting is not only woefully bad in delivering results but also includes a range of questionable practices:Autopilot forecasting: In autopilot forecasting, analysts blindly trust historical data, assuming that prices will not only revert to historical averages, but averages over a specific time period (10 years, 20 years, and so on).
Outsourcing: In many cases, companies and investors turn over forecasting to an outside source, perhaps trusting their expertise but also passing on responsibility.
After all, when the forecasts fail, as they inevitably do, you can blame the forecasting expert.
No accountability: When decisions are made based on forecasted prices, and those forecasts fail, there seems to be little accountability or learning built into the process.
Companies continue to use the same discredited forecasting model or service.
Implicit forecasting: It is worth noting that many companies that explicitly claim not to forecast commodity prices do so implicitly.
Consider airlines, a sector where profitability can be dramatically affected by oil prices, and where you do have instruments that you can use to hedge against future oil price movements.
If you do not have a view on commodity prices, you should either never hedge, and let your investors deal with the resulting earnings volatility, or hedge all the time to give yourself more predictable costs and stable earnings.
Most airlines do neither, choosing not to hedge for stretches of time and hedging the rest.
Much as they would like to claim otherwise, the truth is that their choice of whether to hedge or not to hedge is a reflection of their commodity price views.
They are more likely to hedge when they think oil prices will go up in the future than more likely to stop hedging when they believe the opposite.

 Finally, there are some who seem to operate under the illusion that having a forward market for commodities solves their price forecasting problem.
