That might be true for non-storable commodities, with the market taking on the role of forecasting service, but not for storable commodities, where the futures or forward price is tied to the spot price, to prevent arbitrage possibilities.2

 The Light Side In Chapter 13, on valuing commodity and cyclical companies, we led off by looking at the long lags and leads in commodity production and concluded that estimating the fair value for a commodity (like oil or wheat) from fundamentals is really difficult to do.
We also argued that trying to forecast prices for commodities is a skill that few of us have and that is perhaps where the assessment should begin.
Taking a look at our past forecasting history might lead us to conclude, perhaps reluctantly, that we are incapable of forecasting commodity prices and should therefore stop trying.
It is that conclusion that led us, in Chapter 13, to argue that commodity companies should be valued based on current commodity prices rather than our expectations of future prices.If you decide that there is a chance that you can forecast prices successfully, you need to do the following:Look at long-term price movements: Given length of commodity price cycles, focusing on what might seem like a long period in other contexts, say ten years, can lead to bad forecasts.
It was the mistake that commodity analysts made in 2014, when after commodity prices had dropped substantially in the prior year, they assumed that there would be a quick and strong rebound in prices, based upon average prices over the prior ten years.
They failed to factor in the reality that commodity prices between 2003 and 2012 were abnormally high relative to prices over the prior century, with much of that increase coming from the explosive growth in the Chinese economy.
Use better statistical tools: Averaging prices across long time periods can be the start of your analysis, but it should not be the end.
In addition to adjusting for inflation over time, you should draw on more powerful statistical tools to extract information from the data.
If you are going to play “moneyball” with the data, you might as well do it right.
Watch for structural breaks: Structural breaks are changes in the economy that play out as price changes that are long-term, as opposed to transient.
These breaks can occur on either the demandside or the supply side and can have significant effects on commodity prices.In summary, if you decide to forecast commodity prices, do so with humility, knowing that you will be wrong more often than you would like to be.Currencies A currency is a medium of exchange that you use to denominate cash flows and is a store of purchasing power, if you choose to not invest.
Standing alone, currencies have no cash flows and cannot be valued, but they can be priced against other currencies.

 Drivers of Price In the long term, currencies that are accepted more widely as mediums of exchange and that hold their purchasing power better over time should see their prices rise relative to currencies that don't have those characteristics.
In the short term, though, other forces, including governments trying to manipulate exchange rates, can dominate.

 Using a more conventional currency example, you can see this in Figure 18.1, where we graph the U.S.
$ against seven fiat currencies, where over the long term (1995–2017), you can see the Swiss franc and the Chinese yuan increasing in price, relative to the U.S.
$, and the Mexican peso, Brazilian real, Indian rupee, and British pound dropping in price, again relative to the U.S.
$.
The Japanese yen is a bit of an anomaly, where the low inflation rate in Japan led to an initial appreciation in the currency but a subsequent stagnation in the Japanese economy led to a decline.Figure 18.1 Currency Pricing in the Long Term

 The strength of the Swiss franc over this long period can be attributed to the fact that inflation in Switzerland has stayed lower than inflation in almost every other part of the world, and the weakness of the Brazilian real and Indian rupee over the period reflect the higher inflation in these currencies.
With the Chinese yuan, the booming Chinese economy expanded its use as a medium of exchange.
With the Japanese yen, the benefits of lower inflation in the yen are outweighed by a slowing in the Japanese economy over this period.

 We should note, though, that while the performance of these currencies over the entire period (1995–2017) was in keeping with our hypothesis that a currency’s strength comes from how well it preserves purchasing power and how good it is as a medium of exchange, there were long sub-periods during this same length of time where the exchange rates moved in divergent ways.
For instance, the Brazilian real appreciated almost 250%against the U.S.
$ from January 2003 to September 2008 in spite of Brazilian inflation being much higher than U.S inflation.

 In the short term, it is undeniable that governments and central banks try and sometimes succeed at driving exchange rates up or down for their currencies.
Until the advent of floating (market-set) exchange rates, governments were the arbiters of fixed exchange rates, revaluing and devaluing currencies when it suited them.
That said, it is worth noting that the power of governments and central banks to set exchange rates is often overstated and has decayed over time.
George Soros made his mark as an investor by betting that the British central bankers would not be able to support the British pound, in the face of intense negative sentiment in the market, and he won.

 The Dark Side Making money often looks deceptively easy, playing the pricing game in currency markets, partly because mood and momentum can keep trends going over long periods, even when the underlying economics suggest otherwise.
Not surprisingly, even otherwise intelligent and skeptical players get drawn into playing the currency pricing game either explicitly or implicitly.When played explicitly, this not only includes speculating on currency futures and options, but also manifests itself in the carry trade, where supposedly sophisticated investors borrow money in currencies with low interest rates and lend them in currencies with high interest rates.
If exchange rates don’t change, this is, in effect, easy profit because investors pocket the difference.
When you play it implicitly, it often takes the form of companies and investors investing more of their money in projects and companies in countries whose currencies are appreciating, on the expectations that the currency appreciation will continue into the future.
Finally, companies that borrow in one currency to fund investments that generate cash flows in another are implicitly betting that exchange rates will not adjust to reflect inflation differences.The peril with currency markets is that momentum in the pricing game can shift abruptly, often with little or no reason, and that the profits accumulatedover the long winning run can be wiped out overnight.

 A related pricing game that investors attempt to play with currency markets is built on the trust that governments and central banks are more powerful than they really are, capable of moving exchange rates in directions that they want to and to keep them there, for as long as they desire.
Investors then follow governments and banks on their currency repricing missions, hoping to benefit from the fallout.

 The Light Side If you decide to play the pricing game in currency markets, you should keep in mind the qualities that make some currencies better than others—their acceptance as mediums of exchange and their effectiveness as stores of value.
You should also keep in mind that markets might decide to ignore both in the short term and that currencies will appreciate or depreciate for extended periods for no good (fundamental) reason.

 With currencies, you can choose to play the trading game, where you ride momentum in currency markets for as long as you can but your success will depend on whether you were able to exit early enough, before the momentum shifted.
The tools that you will need to succeed will be momentum-detecting ones and if those take the form of charts and technical analysis, that is what you should use.
If you are a long-term investor, you can play the value game but that game will require that you understand the fundamentals that drive exchange rates over long periods: inflation and real growth in different countries.
You will also have to withstand extended periods where the market does not move in the direction that fundamentals would lead you to believe that they should.

 As with commodity price forecasting, though, the choice that might make the most sense for you is to accept that you are incapable of forecasting exchange rates, either in the near or the long term.
It is the position that we have taken through this entire book when valuing companies with foreign currency exposure.
We used current exchange rates to convert earnings in foreign currency to domestic currency and we assumed that exchange rates would move over time to reflect differential inflation.

 Collectibles You might wonder why we would talk about paintings, sculpture, or baseball cards in a book on valuation, but it remains true that they collectively have significant value and that some individuals have a disproportionate portion of their wealth in them.
Collectibles cannot be valued, but they can be and usually are priced.The Price Determinants We are not experts on collectibles.
At the risk of drawing scorn from experts in the area, we would argue that the price of a collectible is a reflection of two forces:Perception: The first is the perception that a collectible is worth holding, either for aesthetic or emotional reasons.
Unlike assets, where we can point to the magnitude of the cash flows as what separate good assets from bad ones, or commodities, where we trace price to their use in producing goods or services, or currencies, where we look to how well they perform as mediums of exchange or measures of value, the price of a commodity rests on perceptions.
After all, if tomorrow we all make the collective judgment that there is nothing special about Picasso as an artist, the price of his paintings will drop to zero.
Scarcity: For a collectible to be highly priced, it has to be scarce.
With fine art, that scarcity comes from artists being mortal and it remains a morbid truth that the price of art jumps when the artist who created it dies.
With some collectibles, like Tiffany lamps and Mickey Mantle rookie cards, a combination of limited production at the time they were originally made, and time (with lamps getting broken and cards getting damaged), cause the scarcity.Both of these forces are subject to change, with perceptions changing over time, making some collectibles more valuable and some less, and surprise finds making hitherto scarce collectibles less scarce.As with pricing any investment, to price a collectible, you need to be able to standardize prices across the collectible and find similar assets.
The collectibles that are easiest to price come in standardized units and are traded widely, giving you a trove of reliable transaction data that you can

 use in pricing.
The collectibles that are most difficult to price do not come in standardized units and are transacted rarely.
A Topps Ken Griffey rookie card will be far easier to price than Leonardo da Vinci’s Salvator Mundi, a painting that was auctioned off in October 2017.
There are thousands of Ken Griffey rookie cards (albeit with varying degrees of quality), they trade frequently, and the prices at which they trade are visible, making it a relatively simple pricing exercise.
No individual da Vinci painting is like any of his others and few reliable records of prices paid exist for da Vinci paintings in the recent past.

 The Dark Side The way in which collectibles are priced reflects the debate about whether they are investments like stocks, bonds, and real estate or whether they are acquired for aesthetic or emotional reasons.
We believe that the answer will vary depending on the buyer and the collectible in question, but undeniably there are bad practices embedded in the pricing of collectibles:Leave it to the experts: The pricing of collectibles has been long left to experts for the most part, partly because a collectible can be unique and partly because authenticity can be difficult to establish, if you are a novice.
Thus, the owner of a Picasso will call on the experts at Sotheby’s or Christie’s to both authenticate and price the painting for sale and pay a hefty price for the service.
We would argue that turning over the pricing process to experts creates problems of its own.
First, expertise in one area, say Renaissance art, does not necessarily translate into expertise in pricing that art, a very different skill set.
Second, the pricing process with collectibles is remarkably opaque, with a number provided, often with no backing or rationale.
Limited data: The presence of expert-driven pricing has impeded the development of databases of transactions in collectibles that can be used by non-experts to price these collectibles.
It is remarkable, given how much money is invested in collectibles each year, that we do not have better data on transaction specifics.
Pricing process: There are many collectibles where the market price is set at auctions, rather than in open markets, reflecting the scarcity of the collectible and the fact that all you need is a few willing oreven just one willing buyer for the sale to be consummated.
By itself, it might not seem like a big deal, but auction-based pricing is far more difficult to forecast, especially when transactions are few and far between, because the law of large numbers no longer works for you.The bottom line is that collectible pricing, as practiced today, has a data problem, partly because of the paucity of trading in most collectibles and partly because those trades, when they happen, are not easily accessible to future traders.

 The Light Side The collectible market is a large one and there are clearly some who make money in that market.
In fact, a few have argued that collectibles should be part of your investment portfolio, and if you decide to follow their advice, here are some suggestions that you might want to keep in mind.Be clear about motive: When you invest in a collectible, be it a painting, a piece of furniture, or sports memorabilia, you should be clear about your motives in making that investment.
If it is purely for economic reasons, you should approach pricing it just as you would any other traded investment.
Your decision is going to be driven not only by the current price but how you think the price will evolve over time.
If it is for purely for aesthetic or emotional reasons, your intent is not to make money on the collectible but to enjoy holding it.
In this case, you will still want to get it at the lowest price possible, but you are less interested in its price path over time.
Finally, if it is for both economic and emotional reasons, you will be ready to buy the collectible even if its price appreciation potential is less than that of other investments (assets, commodities, or collectibles) you could invest in, but the emotional dividends will cover the difference.
Localized knowledge: If you decide to invest in collectibles for purely economic reasons, there is no excuse for not investing the time and the resources to learn not only more about the collectible but the way the market for the collectible works.
Data: No matter what your motive, you should do your homework, just as you would on any other investment.
You should try to collectas much data as you can on past transactions in the collectible and check these are arms-length transactions.
Fortunately, we are starting to see the beginnings of data services that record this information and analyze it.
Pricing tools: If you have a collectible where transactions are frequent and you can relate prices to fundamentals, you might be able to use statistical tools to get a better handle on the pricing process.
To give you an example, Orley Ashenfelter, a professor at Princeton, developed a statistical model for forecasting the prices of Bordeaux wines, based on the temperature and rainfall of the year of vintage, that did a better job than wine experts.3 With experts, listen, but question: If you do hire an expert to appraise a collectible, you should draw on his or her expertise in appraising its price but you should be willing to ask questions and challenge the findings.
In particular, if you are being assessed a price higher than what others are paying for similar collectibles, you should push on the reasons for the premium and perhaps seek a second opinion.
Stay updated: To make money on collectibles, you not only need to make a judgment of when to buy but you have to be just as careful about when to sell.
That will require keeping tabs on the market, evolving trends, and shifts in tastes that can affect prices.There is no reason that you should not add collectibles to your investment portfolio, but if you decide to do so, you should recognize that this is a pure pricing game that requires localized knowledge.

 In this last grouping, we look at investments that span categories and we argue, with each one, that it has a dominant category that we should put it in.
We start with gold, which is a commodity that derives much of its value from its use as a currency.
We then move on to crypto investments like Bitcoin, Ethereum, and initial coin offerings (ICOs) and argue that they cannot all be put in the same basket, with some being currencies, some commodities, and some assets.
We end with trophy assets, which generate cash flows and can be valued, but where the pricing reflects their standing as collectibles.

 Gold (and Other Precious Metals) Very few investments have shown the staying power of gold.
Through the centuries, across countries, individuals have put their faith in gold as a store of value.
In 2017, it was estimated that there exists almost $8 trillion worth of gold, much of it hidden from markets in vaults and jewelry.
Strictly speaking, gold is a commodity, but in our view, gold is more currency than commodity.

 Gold: Commodity or Currency Gold is a commodity, insofar as it has uses, not only as ornamental jewelry and adornment but in industry as well.
That said, gold would never have its elevated value and standing if it were priced just as a commodity.
For centuries, gold has not only been used as a currency in transactions but as the trust basis for fiat currencies.
After all, until countries abandoned the gold standard, their currencies were backed by gold.
Viewed through that prism, it follows that just as you cannot value the U.S.
dollar or any other fiat currency, you cannot value gold or invest in it.
You can price gold, and trade it.
If we draw on the tenets of currency pricing, that is, that the price of a currency over time, relative to other currencies, will reflect how good it is as a store of value and a medium of exchange, the price of gold should reflect the same qualities.So, how good is gold as a medium of exchange and as a store of value? Although it is not the most convenient currency to carry around for day-to-

 day transactions, it works globally as a medium of exchange for large transactions.
Its long staying power and natural scarcity make it a store of value, but its pricing will depend in large part on how it is perceived to be holding up as a value store, relative to paper currencies.
If, as is commonly argued, gold is an alternative to paper currency, you can argue that the price of gold will be determined by how much trust individuals have in fiat currencies.
That trust, we argue in the next section, waxes and wanes over time, partly as a result of inflation in fiat currencies and partly as a result of economic and political crises that lead to a loss of faith in institutional authorities (governments and central banks).Determinants of Gold Prices If you decide to buy gold, you are making a pricing judgment on gold.
The question of how to make that pricing judgment is one of the oldest and most contested questions in investing.
There are three broad drivers of the gold price over time.

 Inflation It is widely believed that if the value of paper currency is debased by inflation, gold will gain in value.
To see whether the widely held view of gold as a hedge against inflation has a basis, we looked at changes in gold prices and the inflation rate each year from 1963–2016, shown in Figure 18.2:Figure 18.2 Gold Prices and InflationThe co-movement of gold and inflation is particularly strong in the 1970s, a decade where the U.S.
economy was plagued by high inflation, and the correlation between gold prices and the inflation rate is brought home when you regress returns on gold against the inflation rate for the entire period:

 Although this regression does back the conventional view of gold as an inflation hedge, there are two potential weak spots.
The first is that the R- squared is only 23.5%, suggesting that factors other than inflation have a significant effect on gold prices.
The second is that removing the 1970s essentially removes much of the significance from this regression.
In fact, while the large move in gold prices in the 1970s can be explained by unexpectedly high inflation during the decade, the rise of gold prices between 2001 and 2012 cannot be attributed to inflation.
In fact, taking a closer look at the data, it is clear that gold is more a hedge against extreme(and unexpected) inflation and that it does not really provide much protection against smaller inflation changes.

 Crises Through the centuries, gold has been the asset of last resort for investors fleeing a crisis.
Thus, as investor fears ebb and flow, gold prices should go up and down.
To test this effect, we looked at two forward-looking measures of investor fears—the default spread on a Baa-rated bond and the implied equity risk premium (which is the forward-looking premium computed based on stock prices and expected cash flows; refer to Chapter 7).
As investor fears increase, you should expect to see these premiums in both the equity and the bond market increase.
Figure 18.3 captures the co- movements.Figure 18.3 Gold Prices and Risk PremiaWhile the relationship is harder to decipher than the one with inflation, higher equity risk premiums and default spreads correlate with higher gold prices.
However, the relationship is weak and as with inflation, it mightwork only for extreme periods; that is, when crises drive risk premiums up significantly in stock and bond markets.

 Real Interest Rates One of the costs of holding gold is that while you hold it, you lose the return you could have made investing it in a financial asset.
The magnitude of this opportunity cost is captured by the real interest rate, with higher real interest rates translating into much higher opportunity costs and thus lower prices for gold.
The real interest rate can be measured directly used the inflation-indexed Treasury bond (TIPs) rate or indirectly by netting out the expected inflation from a nominal risk-free (or close to risk-free) rate.
Figure 18.4 looks at gold price movements, relative to the real interest rate.Figure 18.4 Gold Prices and Real Interest RatesNote that the real interest rate is computed as the difference between the ten-year U.S.
Treasury bond rate in that year and the realized inflation rate (rather than the expected inflation rate).
Regressing changes in gold prices against the real interest rate yields the following:Annual% Change in Gold Price = 0.24 − 6.59 (T.Bond Rate-Inflation Rate) R2 = 33.2%High real interest rates are a negative for gold prices and low real interest rates push gold prices higher.The Dark Side People have been investing in gold for millennia, but the decision to do so often seems to have its roots in emotions rather than economics.
There are three reasons why gold investors disappointed:Paranoia and mistrust: Through the ages, investors have been drawn to gold during periods of uncertainty and crisis.
Although gold’s utility as a crisis currency is part of its allure, some gold investors seem to see crises behind every problem, converting tremors into earthquakes and overreact by not just putting more of their portfolios into gold than they should, but often leaving it there for too long.
Unreal expectations: In addition to investing large portions of their portfolio in gold, many gold investors seem to have unrealistic expectations of the returns they can expect to generate over time.
Specifically, they seem to ignore evidence that, over long time periods, the actual returns on gold tend to be lower than the returns on most other asset classes and that there is no reason to believe that the future will be different.
Over the last 50 years, for instance, the annual return on gold has been less than 7% a year, disappointing if you have bought into the sales hype that gold will make you rich.
Pricing magic: If gold is a currency, investing in it is a pricing game.
That said, traders in gold who play the pricing game seem to do so with very little data, often limited to historical data on gold (and charts of that data) and primitive tools (averaging historical prices or comparing gold to silver prices).It is surprising that these practices have remained largely unchanged through the centuries, but one reason might be that the most dedicatedinvestors in gold seem to view any suggestion that there are better ways to invest in gold as an affront.

 The Light Side There are some who believe that there are no good reasons for investing in gold, but we believe that they are wrong.
In fact, there is no reason why gold should not be part of a value investor’s portfolio, if that investor is realistic about what gold will bring in terms of benefits.
If you are a good trader, there might be ways to play the pricing game on gold to your advantage.

 Gold as Insurance In the last section, we pointed to evidence that gold has operated as a hedge against inflation, at least during high inflation periods, and as a crisis asset, holding its value intact or rising during financial and political crises.
Those features of gold can make it an attractive add-on investment to a portfolio composed primarily of financial assets (stocks and bonds).
Financial assets are generally not good hedges against inflation and both bonds and stocks are hurt by unexpectedly high inflation.
Adding gold to a portfolio of stocks and bonds can provide at least partial insurance against inflationary episodes.
Statistically, this can be seen in the correlation between stocks, treasuries, and gold reported in Table 18.2.Table 18.2 Correlation between Gold and Financial Asset Returns—1968 to 2016

 Note that gold is negatively correlated with stocks and bonds.
There are two other considerations to take into account in making the judgments of whether to add gold to a portfolio.
The first is to recognize that gold is not a perfect hedge and that it does not seem to work well to cover small increases in inflation.
The second is that alternative and cleaner hedges against inflation exist, including futures on the inflation index, which might work better than gold over short time periods.

 Gold as a Trade If the essence of success in trading is buying at a low price and selling at a high one, winning that game in gold will require building a pricing model that works at forecasting future movements in gold prices and shifts in momentum.
Broadly speaking, two variants of these forecasting models exist:The median value is 2.66 for the 1963–2016 time period and the average value is 3.11.
At the year-end price in October 2017, gold prices were high relative to the CPI.
To the extent that we buy into this long-term indicator, that would suggest that gold prices are more likely to go down than up.
Against other precious metals: Another way that you can frame the relative value of gold is against other precious metals.
For instance, you can price gold relative to silver, and make a judgment on whether it is cheap or expensive.
In November 2017, the gold price was $1,248.20/ounce and the silver price was $15.83/ounce, yielding a ratio of 78.84 for gold to silver prices (1248.2/15.83).
To get a measure of where this number stands in a historical context, we looked at the ratio of gold prices to silver prices from 1963 to 2016, as shown in Figure 18.6.The median value of 53.51 over the 1963–2016 period suggests that gold is overpriced, relative to silver.

 Crypto Investments The decade between 2008 and 2017 saw the birth of crypto investments, with Bitcoin leading the way but followed by an array of other variants, including Ethereum and initial coin offerings (ICO).
As they have soared in price, the questions about what to categorize them as and whether they are fairly valued have followed.
While it is still early in the game, we can still develop a framework for thinking about how to answer these questions.
The crypto investment category includes a wide variety of investments.
At one end of the spectrum are the crypto currencies like Bitcoin that aspire either to be digital currencies that are widely used or niche currencies, akin to gold.
In the middle are crypto commodities like Ethereum that market themselves not as full-fledged currencies but as lubricants for smart contracting or block chains, hoping to generate their value from growth in these categories.
Finally, there are crypto assets such as initial coin units, used by companies in need of capital, as an alternative to conventional equity.

 Crypto Currencies A crypto currency is a digital currency, promoted by its proponents as a replacement for fiat currencies.
Rather than talk in abstractions, consider Bitcoin, which has the highest profile of the crypto currencies.
While there are others who trace its lineage back to earlier research, it is widely accepted that Bitcoin in its current form can be traced back to Satoshi Nakamoto’s paper on its architecture, published in October 2008 and made open source in January 2009.
His creation has succeeded beyond his wildest dreams, and by 2017, the price per Bitcoin had risen to above $15,000, with a total value of all units in existence in excess of $200 billion.

 The Mechanics of Bitcoin While the crypto currencies have their differences, the most successful ones share a base architecture, the block chain.
A block chain is a shared digital ledger of transactions in an asset where the validation of transactions is decentralized.
Figure 18.7 illustrates the way a block chain works to facilitate a bitcoin transaction.Figure 18.7 The Block Chain ProcessThe key features of a block chain are the following:Decentralized verification: The validation and verification of a transaction is sourced to members, called miners in the crypto trying different currency world.
Verification usually algorithms (hashes) to find the unique one that matches the transaction block, and the successful miner is rewarded, currently with the crypto currency.
This process requires more brute force (powerful processors trying different algorithms before you find a match) than intellectual firepower.
Complete and open records: Every transaction, once validated and verified, is converted into a block of data that is recorded in the block chain ledger, which is accessible to everyone in the network.
If you are worried about privacy, the transaction records do not include personal data but take the form of encrypted data (hashes).
Incorruptible: A block chain, once recorded and shared, cannot be changed because those changes are visible to everyone in the network and are quickly tagged as fraudulent.
Thus, the ledger, once created, becomes almost incorruptible.

 In effect, a block chain is a digital intermediation process where transactions are checked by members of the network and recorded, and after which cannot be altered fraudulently.
As you can see from its description, the block chain technology is about far more than crypto currencies.
It can be used to record transactions in any asset, from securities in financial markets to physical assets like houses, and do so in a way that replaces the existing intermediaries with decentralized models.
It should come as no surprise that banks and stock exchanges, which make the bulk of their money from intermediation, not only see block chains as a threat to their existence but have been early investors in the technology, hoping to co-opt it to their own needs.

 Pricing Bitcoin The first step toward a serious debate on Bitcoin then has to be deciding whether it is an asset, a currency, a commodity, or collectible.
In our view, Bitcoin is not an asset, because it does not generate cash flows standing alone for those who hold it (until they sell it).
It is not a commodity, because it is not raw material that can be used in the production of something useful.
The choice then becomes whether it is a currency or a collectible, with its supporters tilting toward the former and its detractors the latter.
If Bitcoin is a currency, it is not a good one yet (as of late 2017), insofar as it has only limited acceptance as a medium of exchange and it is too volatile to be a store of value.
Looking forward, we see three possible paths for Bitcoin as a currency, from best case to worst case.The global digital currency: In the best-case scenario, Bitcoin gains wide acceptance in transactions across the world, becoming a widely used global digital currency.
For this to happen, it has to become more stable (relative to other currencies), central banks and governments around the world have to accept its use (or at least not actively try to impede it), and the aura of mystery around it has to fade.
If that happens, it could compete with fiat currencies and given the algorithm-set limits on its creation, its high price could be justified.
Gold for millennials: In this scenario, Bitcoin becomes a haven for those who do not trust central banks, governments, and fiat currencies.
In short, it takes on the role that gold has, historically, forthose who have lost trust in or fear centralized authority.
It is interesting that the language of Bitcoin is filled with mining terminology, because it suggests that intentionally or otherwise, the creators of Bitcoin shared this vision.
In fact, the hard cap on Bitcoin of 21 million is more compatible with this scenario than the first one.
If this scenario unfolds, and Bitcoin shows the same staying power as gold, it will behave like gold does, rising during crises and dropping in more sanguine time periods.
The twenty-first century tulip bulb: In this, the worst-case scenario, Bitcoin will be a shooting star, attracting more money as it soars (from those who see it as a source of easy profits) but just as quickly flaring out, as these traders move on to something new and different (which could be a different and better-designed digital currency), leaving Bitcoin holders with memories of what might have been.
If this happens, Bitcoin could very well become the equivalent of tulip bulbs, a speculative asset that saw its prices soar in the 1600s in Holland, before collapsing in the aftermath.

 We do not know which of these scenarios will unfold, but they are all still plausible scenarios.
If you are trading in Bitcoin, you might very well not care, because your time horizon might be in minutes and hours, not weeks, months, or years.
If you have a longer-term interest in Bitcoin, though, your focus should be less on the noise of day-to-day price movements and more on advancements on its use as a currency.Crypto Commodities and Assets Although Bitcoin has hogged the limelight in the crypto investment space, other crypto investments are not marketed as currencies and require being viewed through very different lenses.is much better suited for the smart contracting process, because it is designed for them.
If you buy into that argument, the demand for Ethereum will be tied to the growth of smart contracts and its pricing will follow.
A crypto asset gives you a right to cash flows and it can be argued that initial coin offerings (ICOs) can be structured to fit the bill.
Young start-up companies can use ICOs to raise capital and an ICO can be constructed to give its buyer a share of the ownership in a business (and the cash flows from that business).
The lack of standardization in ICO structures, though, makes it difficult to generalize, because loosely put, an ICO can be constructed to be anything from a donation, with no contractual claims to cash flows, to quasi-common stock.
Put differently, to value an ICO, you need to not only value the underlying business but also be familiar with the rights of the ICO holder to cash flows.As crypto commodities and assets evolve, we will see whether they deliver on their promise, but we will also see more standardization and regulation, partly because of scandals and overreach on the part of both issuers and investors.

 The Dark Side of Crypto Currencies As with any other investment, there is no reason why you cannot invest or perhaps even trade in crypto investments as long as you are clear about what it is you are investing in.
Many of the worst practices in crypto investing reflect the fact that crypto investments have been around only a few years and investors are still learning about what they are and how to value or price them.
That said, the rise in their prices has laid bare some of the weaknesses in this investment class:Pricing perils: These are young markets, almost entirely driven by pricing considerations.
Because pricing requires comparables and the crypto investment market is so young, many investors reach for comparisons that make no sense.
Thus, some argued in 2017 that Bitcoin had room to run because its estimated market value of $200 billion was well below the value of gold in the world, which amounted to $8 trillion.
No differentiation: As the crypto investment market has expanded with new offerings, some investors seem to be painting the market with a broad brush, treating all crypto investments as equivalent.
As we argued in the last section, big differences exist between crypto currencies, crypto assets, and crypto commodities and they need different analytical tools.The turmoil and confusion in the crypto investment is neither new nor unexpected.
It has always taken investors a while to get used to new investment classes and the learning often comes with pain.

 The Light Side of Crypto Currencies To incorporate crypto investments into a portfolio, we need to step away from both extremes of the debate.
Unlike some skeptics, we do not believe that crypto investments are a fraud and that anyone investing in them is therefore a dupe.
At the same time, we disagree with those who seem to believe that crypto investments can change fundamental business models and that they have unlimited value.
As this market evolves, we suggest the following:Categorize clearly: It is important that rather than treat crypto investments as a class, you break the class down into components and classify each offering into whether it is currency, commodity, asset, or collectible.
Price or value: After it is classified, you have to be clear-eyed about pricing and valuing that investment.
If, as with Bitcoin, you conclude that a crypto investment is a currency, you cannot value it, but only price it.
It also follows that you cannot invest in Bitcoin, only trade it, and that requires pricing tools.
If you’re looking at an ICO, structured to give you a claim on cash flows of a business, you can both valueand price it, just as you would any stock.
You can then decide whether you will invest in the ICO, buying if the price is less than value, or trade the ICO, making bets on future price movements.
Track the fundamentals: Ultimately, a crypto investment has to deliver on its promised purpose for its price to stay afloat.
With Bitcoin, that implies that the test of its pricing will be whether you see Bitcoin used more extensively in transactions in the future.
With Ethereum, a commodity tied to smart contracts, its value will come from the growth in smart contracting and whether contract users prefer to denominate them in Ethereum.The risks in this market for investors are high, but the opportunities are as well.

 Trophy Assets Trophy assets include a range of assets from big name real estate properties like the Waldorf Astoria to professional sports teams.
Trophy assets are assets because they generate cash flows and can be valued as assets, but investors are willing to pay far more for the “trophy” part of the assets.
Put differently, those who buy and sell these assets are less interested in them as cash flow-generating assets and more as collectibles that they can use to advance their social status, flaunt to their friends, or use as expensive play toys.

 The Determinants of Value/Price Trophy assets often become valuation puzzles, because their capacity to generate cash flows makes them amenable to conventional valuation approaches, but the values that you arrive at are puzzling, because they are so much lower than the prices at which these assets sell.
That is because those who buy trophy assets are willing to pay a premium over the value for the same reasons that they pay premium prices for collectibles.
The determinants of the premium are therefore the same ones that we highlighted for collectibles.
First, the premium will increase with scarcity, with scarcer trophy assets earning higher premiums.
Second, the premium will be higher for trophy assets with high profiles, with names that are widely recognized and respected.

 This combination might explain the surge in prices for sports franchises around the world.
Thus, the NFL (American football), NBA (American basketball), Premier and European league soccer, and the IPL (Indian cricket) have all seen dramatic increases in prices paid for teams.
It is difficult, no matter how optimistic you might be about television and merchandising revenues in these sports, to justify the transaction prices, but it becomes less difficult to explain if you bring in the reality that there are very wealthy individuals who will pay a premium over the price to own one of these teams.The Dark Side When an asset becomes a trophy asset, its pricing will rise relative to its value.
Investors who are blind to this transition will expose themselves to risk on multiple fronts:Value focus: Investors with a value focus have long been taught that an asset that trades at a price higher than the value is overvalued and that markets correct their mistakes.
Although that might be a solid investment philosophy with conventional assets, it can be dangerous with trophy assets, especially if investors decide to act on the overvaluation by selling short on the asset.
Because the premium over the value with trophy assets is not a pricing mistake but a collectible premium, no reason exists why it should dissipate over time.
The investor who sold short will discover this too late and will be poorer as a consequence.
Bigger fool pricing: The nature of trophy asset pricing is that detecting shifts in mood and momentum in this market is far more difficult than in the asset, currency, or commodity markets.
That is because the trophy asset class has only a small number of assets in it (because the scarcity creates the trophy prefix) and the investors in this market are often not investing for economic reasons.The rise in prices of trophy assets sometimes draws unsuspecting investors and traders into the market, and unless they recognize the differences between trophy assets and other investments, they will lose.The Light Side The key to investing wisely with trophy assets is recognizing that they are trophy assets, because it generates logical implications:Investors, stay away: If you are an investor, focused on cash flows and value, the best course of action is to stay away from trophy assets in your investing.
The premium that some are willing to pay for these assets will result in prices that are well in excess of value, thus making them overvalued.
At the same time, the fact that these premiums have little to do with economic objectives makes it likely that the pricing mistakes will not get corrected over time.
Traders, be cautious: If you are a trader, you have to be cautious about jumping into trophy asset markets, because price movements are unpredictable.
That said, opportunities exist.
Identifying an asset class on the verge of becoming a trophy class can be extremely lucrative, because their prices will skyrocket when that happens.
If you had bought or invested in an NFL and NBA team two decades ago, that investment would have multiplied in price as wealthy owners piled into the market.
Trophy enhancement: One final twist exists to the trophy asset game that existing owners of these assets can play.
To the extent that the trophy premium that investors are willing to pay increases with the public profile of the asset, actions that you take as owners can change value.
Manchester United, the New York Yankees, and the Dallas Cowboys all enjoy high pricing because they are global franchises, with a standing that extends well beyond the cities or countries that they operate.
Mark Cuban’s capacity for promotion has played a significant role in the rise in pricing of not just the Dallas Mavericks, the NBA franchise that he owns, but all NBA franchises.

 Investments exist that cannot be valued and recognizing that fact can not only save us time, but frustration.
In this chapter, we broke investments down into four classes, starting with cash flow–generating assets, moving on to currencies and commodities, and closing with collectibles.
Cash flow– generating assets can be valued or priced, and you can decide whether you want to be an investor, deciding what to buy and sell based upon a comparison of value to price, or a trader, where your focus is primarily on pricing.
You can only price currencies against each other, based upon how good they are as mediums of exchange and stores of value, but you cannot value them.
It follows then that you can only trade currencies, not invest in them.
With commodities, valuation will require making judgments about large macroeconomic trends and is often difficult to do, leaving pricing as the more used option.
Finally, collectibles like fine art can only be priced.

 This framework can help us navigate our way through hybrid investments that fall into more than one category.
Gold is a commodity but is clearly priced more as a currency.
It follows then that the price of gold has little to do with the uses that you can put gold to, or even its production, and more to do with how people perceive it as a currency.
Crypto investments range the spectrum from crypto currencies like Bitcoin, which can only be priced, to ICOs, which can be valued and priced.
Finally, trophy assets can be valued as assets but trade at prices that reflect their collectible premium.

 Throughout this book, we have emphasized the importance of first principles in valuation and how they should guide us when we’re faced with estimation questions and issues.
The dark side of valuation, as we have described it, takes different forms with different types of firms.
The remedies we offer also vary with each type.
This chapter pulls together some of the core ideas that allow us to combat the pull of the dark side.
In the process, we quickly review the foundations of what we would like to portray as the enlightened side of valuation.When confronted with uncertainty or missing information, we are tempted to adopt loosely backed rules of thumb and make inconsistent assumptions about growth, risk, and cash flows.
The following sections outline a few propositions that can guide us in making better judgments and estimates, and result in better valuations.

 Proposition 1: Be Steadfast on Principles, Open to New Tools, and Flexible on Estimates A principle is a core idea, a tool is what you use to put that idea into practice, and an estimate is what emerges from that tool.
We should never compromise on a few basic principles in valuation, no matter what the counterarguments are.
They include the following: (a) that an asset derives its value from its capacity to generate cash flows in the future, (b) that risk affects value, (c) that growth has to be earned (not endowed), and (d) that the laws of demand and supply cannot be repealed.
An analyst who argues that firms can grow forever without reinvesting is violating a first principle.
Lest this be seen as a sign of rigidity, we would hasten to add that we should always be willing to compromise on, and accept, better tools, and be open to alternative estimates for inputs into value.

 To illustrate, the notion that the value of an asset should be a function of its risk is a first principle, but the capital asset pricing model (CAPM) is a tool for estimating risk.
The regression beta we obtain is an estimate of that risk.
We will not be swayed in our belief that an asset’s value should be determined by its risk.
But we should be willing to adapt, modify, or even abandon the CAPM if the data suggests that we should.
As for the beta, we should use whichever approach gives us the best estimate, and that approach can vary across firms.
In summary, then, we will remain steadfast in our belief that risk should affect value and be open to new developments when it comes to models for estimating that risk.
Furthermore, we will always be on the lookout for better and more consistent estimates of risk parameters.

 Proposition 2: Pay Heed to Markets, but Don’t Let Them Determine Your Valuations Many of the companies that we are called on to value are traded in financial markets and have market prices.
Without making any judgments about markets or their efficiency, we believe that there is valuable information in how the market is pricing assets.
In fact, our estimates of risk-free rates in Chapter 6 and equity risk premiums in Chapter 7 came from financial markets—the pricing of Treasury bonds for the first, and the level of equity indices for the latter.
When valuing a company, we should pay attention to the market price for two reasons:The information we extract from markets on implied growth rates, risk, and cash flows can be used to improve our valuations.
Ultimately, we make money not from our estimates of intrinsic values, but from the market prices moving to those intrinsic values.
Thus, we need to understand why market prices deviate from value and how they will adjust over time.

 At the same time, paying too much attention to markets (and prices) can lead to paralysis, because there is always an alternative set of assumptions under which the market price is justified.
In other words, if we start by assuming that the market is always right, we will end up confirming that assumption in our valuations.

 We face a balancing act when we use market inputs for some numbers (risk- free rates, equity risk premium, market weights for debt, and equity in the cost of capital) and argue that the market is wrong on other dimensions.
To derive reasonable values for companies, we have to decide early on in a valuation which inputs we will accept market inputs on and for which ones we will contest the market consensus.
In Chapters 6 and 7, we argued that when valuing individual companies, we should accept the market consensus on risk-free rates and equity risk premiums and focus our attention or estimating the company’s earnings and cash flows.
In Chapter 13, when valuing an oil company, we made a case for using market-consensus prices for oil prices (obtained from either the spot market or the forward and futures markets).
We also limited our valuation to how much oil the company would produce and its cost structure.

 As a general rule, the areas where you choose to accept market wisdom and the points at which you deviate depend on two key variables.
The first is in the competitive advantages you see yourself having as an analyst and where you think these advantages will generate the biggest payoff.
If your edge is in forecasting macroeconomic movements and oil prices, you will replace the market prices for oil with your own estimates and leverage your edge to generate better valuations.
On the other hand, if your biggest strength is in assessing a company’s internal strengths, you should not be expending resources estimating macro parameters.
The second factor is your job description.
If your job is to assess the value of individual companies, not to assess the overall market or commodity prices, you will be doing yourself and your clients a disservice by letting your views on macroeconomic variables seep into your company valuations.
We would argue that most equity research analysts and appraisers fall into this category and should not build their market views into their valuations.

 Proposition 3: Risk Matters It is true that considerable resources have been invested in both academia and practice in coming up with models to assess risk and derive expected returns.
It is also true that these models often make assumptions about the real world that do not withstand close scrutiny.
In the capital asset pricing model, for instance, we assume no transaction costs and private information to derive the relationship between expected returns and betas.
Analysts, looking at these models, find themselves disagreeing with the assumptions.
That is perfectly understandable, but jumping from that disagreement to a conclusion that risk does not matter in value is not.
Because risk assessment and measures are often at the heart of the dark side of valuation, the following list summarizes some of the ideas about risk that we have discussed in prior chapters:increase value.
These assets have limited downsides and very large upsides, thus taking on the characteristics of options.
We considered varied examples in earlier chapters, from young high-growth companies with proprietary technologies in Chapter 9, to equity in deeply levered, distressed companies in Chapter 12, to undeveloped oil reserves in Chapter 13.
Not all risk is equal: If there is one lesson we should take away from the last few decades of examining risk, it is that all risks are not equal.
Some risks affect only one firm or a few firms, whereas other risks have consequences for a wider subset of firms and sometimes for the overall market.
When assessing risk for valuation, it is therefore imperative that we first identify the marginal investors (active investors with large stockholdings) in a firm and look at risk through their eyes.
If the marginal investor is diversified, the only risks that should affect value are the market or macro risks that cannot be diversified away.
In contrast, though, if the marginal investor is undiversified or only partially diversified, we should look at a much broader set of risks, including firm-specific risks.
In Chapter 9, this was the insight we used to derive total betas and costs of equity for entrepreneurs (who tend not to be diversified) and venture capitalists (who are only partially diversified).
Continuous versus discrete risk: Risk can be divided into two categories.
Continuous risk affects cash flows and value continuously over time.
Examples are interest rate risk and exchange rate risk.
Discrete or discontinuous risk might lie dormant for long periods but affect value significantly when it occurs.
The risk of default and nationalization are examples.
We argued that continuous risk is best captured in discount rates, whereas discrete risk is more easily measured by assessing both the probability and consequences of the event occurring.
We used the latter technique to adjust the values of young growth companies and distressed companies for survival risk, and emerging-market companies for nationalization risk.As we build risk into valuation models, adopting the following practices is also important:Thus, the effect of emerging-market risk is captured in the country risk premium but does not affect risk-free rates, betas, or cash flows.
There are two reasons why this is a good practice.
The first is that it prevents the double-or triple-counting of risk.
The second is that it allows for more transparency.
Thus, those who use the valuation can assess the risk adjustment made and decide whether they agree with it.
If they disagree, making the change and re-estimating value are relatively simple.
Be consistent: When valuing firms, especially growth firms or firms in trouble, we have to recognize that the firm’s risk profile will change over time and must adjust the risk parameters accordingly.
With growth firms, for instance, the high discount rates we use in the early years (reflecting the risk in those years) have to come down as growth declines.
In almost all the valuations we have presented in this book, the betas and discount rates we use for the terminal value reflect this judgment.As investors, we can invest in bonds, assets, or stocks, and in domestic or foreign markets.
Therefore, we need to use the same rules when assessing expected returns across asset classes and markets.

 Proposition 4: Growth Is Not Free and Is Not Always Value- Adding If a theme exists in our discussions of growth across the chapters, it is that growth is not free.
Ultimately, the expected growth in a company’s earnings and cash flows must come from either new investments or improved efficiency.
The latter is finite growth—there is a limit to how efficient you can become as a firm—whereas new investment growth can be for the long term (and potentially forever).

 It is also critical to remember that growth by itself is not always a plus for a company, because the value added by growth is a function of the quality of the investments that generated that growth.
That is why we have focused so intensely on excess returns, estimated by comparing the return on capital to the cost of capital, or the return on equity to the cost of equity, in our assessments of growth.
A firm that grows by investing in new assets that generate a return on capital equal to its cost of capital will become larger

 over time, but it will not add value for its investors.
A firm that grows by investing in poor investments—that is, the return on capital (or equity) is less than the cost of capital (or equity)—will become less valuable over time, even as it grows.
In fact, a key test of managers is whether they can generate high excess returns while reinvesting significant amounts into the business.

 In the context of relative valuation, we might not be directly focused on excess returns, but we should pay attention to them.
Thus, if two companies are expected to deliver the same expected growth in earnings in the future, the company that has the higher excess returns accompanying this growth should be valued more highly.

 Proposition 5: All Good Things Come to an End In addition to looking at the value added or destroyed by growth, we often have to make estimates of future growth rates for companies.
In making this assessment, we must pay attention to two key variables.
The first is the scaling effect.
As companies get bigger, it becomes more and more difficult for them to keep delivering the excess returns and growth rates they did in the past.
Thus, it is almost a certainty that a firm that has grown 100% a year for the last three years will grow at a slower rate in the next three years.
With the young growth companies discussed in Chapter 9, we reflected this reality by lowering expected growth rates in revenues and earnings as we move through time.
The second factor is competition.
When firms are successful, they attract attention, which in turn leads to imitation and increased competition.
Although firms might be successful at keeping this competition at bay for extended periods (using legal and other tools), the new competitors will inevitably chip away at profitability and growth.

 One way we reflected the inevitability of declining growth is by assuming that all firms, no matter how highly regarded they might be now, eventually will become stable-growth firms.
(And, at that point, we estimate a terminal value.) We captured the effects of competition over time by pushing the margins of individual firms to the industry average and the returns on capital (or equity) toward the cost of equity (or capital).

 Proposition 6: Watch Out for Truncation Risk In conventional discounted cash flow valuation, we value firms as going concerns, with cash flows continuing into perpetuity.
Although this might not be an unreasonable assumption for some firms, the reality is that most firms do not make it to this stable-growth phase.
Many young firms run out of cash and have to shut down, some mature firms become the targets of acquirers, and most distressed firms end up defaulting on debt and going out of business.
The optimism that underlies discounted cash flow valuation can lead us to overestimate the values of firms, where the risk of not making it (truncation risk) is high.

 In Part III, we argued that the risk of truncation is greatest for firms at either end of the life cycle—very young growth companies and declining or distressed companies.
With these firms, we adopt a two-step approach to valuation.
In the first, we assume that the firms will not only survive but also become profitable and healthy over time, and we value them on that basis.
In the second step, we estimate the likelihood that they will not survive and the values for the firm and equity in the event of failure.
Our final estimate of value is a weighted average of the two numbers.

 Proposition 7: Look at the Past, but Think About the Future One of the conundrums we face in valuation is that although almost all the data we have available to us is about the past, reflecting the company’s history (past financial statements, betas), the sector (industry average margins and returns on capital), and macroeconomic variables (interest rates, exchange rates, stock returns), all the forecasts we have to make are for the future.
Although we cannot manufacture data for the future, we can follow some simple rules to minimize the damage:cycle.
Consequently, we normalized earnings for these companies using the information in the company’s own history as well as in the commodity price cycle.
Trust in mean reversion, but watch out for structural breaks and changes: Whenever we use historical data to make forecasts, we are that mean reversion exists.
In other words, both assuming macroeconomic numbers, such as inflation and interest rates, and company-specific information, such as margins and reinvestment rates, revert to historic norms.
While mean reversion has strong empirical support, two dangers are associated with assuming that it will happen.
The first is that there can sometimes be significant breaks in history, where the circumstances change so much that the numbers are unlikely to revert for a very long period to past averages.
This was the case, for instance, in the U.S.
in the 1970s, when inflation increased and pushed up interest rates and commodity prices for almost a decade.
The second danger is that there is no consensus on what exactly the historical norm is for most variables.
Different analysts can look at the same data and come to very different judgments about what constitutes normalcy.
Use forward looking estimates as alternatives or checks: With a few variables, we might be able to get forward-looking estimates that can be used either directly in valuation or to check the historical data.
With equity risk premiums in Chapter 7, for instance, the implied equity risk premium we estimated, based on the current level of the equity index and the expected future cash flows, offers an alternative to historical risk premiums.
With oil prices, futures and forward markets provide estimates that can be used to value companies, rather than past data.
We can either replace the historical estimates with these forward-looking numbers or adjust them to reflect differences.

 We should be glad that valuation is not just an exercise in taking last year’s numbers and putting them through a model.
After all, if this were the case, there would be no need for human intervention, because a computer could very easily accomplish this task.
Our role in valuation is to look at past data, assess its usefulness, and then make our best predictions for the future.

 Proposition 8: Draw on the Law of Large Numbers One of the issues we have raised as a manifestation of the dark side is the use of rules of thumb in valuations.
These rules can range anywhere from a fixed equity risk premium (obtained from a service) to adding premiums to value for control, synergy, and other “good” factors and subtracting discounts for illiquidity and poor corporate governance.
In many cases, the numbers that are used in these adjustments come from looking at past data.
The historical equity risk premium, for instance, is estimated by averaging the premium earned by stocks over treasuries over long time periods.
The control premium (of 20%) is roughly what acquirers have paid to acquire publicly traded target firms over an extended period.
Even if these estimates are constantly updated and are from services that have impeccable reputations, these numbers cannot be treated as facts.
They are estimates, based on samples, and they come with substantial standard errors.
Thus, a historical equity risk premium of 4%, estimated with 50 years of data in the U.S., has a standard error of about 3% associated with it, just as the acquisition premium of 20% has a standard error of about 5% attached to it.While making estimates based on data will always be subject to noise, we can do some things to make these estimates more precise:

 We should make a final point about the law of large numbers.
Because the values we obtain for individual companies are estimates, the likelihood that we will be wrong about any one company in any one period is high.
However, if we assess value well, our chances of being right will improve if we extend to multiple periods (longer time horizons) and across multiple stocks (portfolios).

 Proposition 9: Accept Uncertainty, and Deal with It We noted early in this book that one of the reasons we are attracted to the dark side of valuation is because we feel overwhelmed by the uncertainties we face with some groups of companies.
In fact, much of this book has been directed at developing healthier responses to uncertainty:Accept uncertainty: Accept uncertainty as a given, and understand that no matter how carefully we construct models, we cannot make uncertainty go away.
Thus, adding more detail to models or making models more complicated, both of which are tactics that analysts use to reduce uncertainty, often does little to alleviate the problem and might actually make it worse.
Ask what-if questions, but for the right reasons: As access to data improves and more sophisticated tools for dealing with uncertainty (Monte Carlo simulations, decision trees) are introduced, we are also seeing the potential downside of allowing analysts to subject their valuations to these tools.
The first problem is that these tools often require complex inputs, and the quality of the output is a function of the quality of the inputs.
Simulations, for instance, require us to choose probability distributions for our inputs and parameters for the distributions.
This is a difficult task considering the data we can access.
The second problem is that some analysts use these as toolsfor risk adjustment rather than risk assessment.
In the process, they double-count risk.
Consider a discounted cash flow valuation of a firm, where expected cash flows are discounted back at a risk- adjusted rate to arrive at a value that is higher than the current market prices.
Assume that you put this model through a Monte Carlo simulation, derive a distribution of values (which suggests that there is a 40% chance that the stock is overvalued), and decide not to invest in the firm on this basis.
You have double-counted risk—once by using risk-adjusted rates, and again by drawing on the results of the simulation.In summary, uncertainty and risk are part of life and investing.
When valuing companies, we can demand a premium for taking this risk in the discount rate and arrive at a risk-adjusted value, but it will change as circumstances change.

 Proposition 10: Value = Stories + Numbers Two forces undercut the quality of valuations.
The first is access to data— online searches and powerful modeling tools are converting many valuations into modeling exercises, where elaborate and complex models become black boxes that spit out numbers.
The second is that we live in a world of specialization, where we work with people who often think like us, and in these echo chambers, it is hard to find disagreement.

 If we increasingly are becoming tribes of number crunchers and storytellers who talk past each other and cannot understand the other tribe, then valuation requires us to not only to learn to talk to each other but also to work on our weak sides.
As a number cruncher, I found that I had no faith in my own valuations until I learned how to tell stories that not only backed up my numbers but also bound my numbers together.
If you are a storyteller, you will find yourself becoming more disciplined if you can pick up some number-crunching skills.

 One of the critiques of discounted cash flow valuation is that it is so focused on numbers that it misses the qualitative variables.
Included in the list of qualitative variables are items such as customer loyalty, brand name, and good management.
This can be true in some cases, where few questions are asked about the numbers and the inputs are mostly exogenous.
We hope

 that we have addressed this criticism directly, as we have valued individual companies.
Every number in a discounted cash flow valuation should have an economic rationale—a good economic story behind it.
Thus, when we set a firm’s return on capital at 15%, well above its cost of capital, it behooves us to think about this firm’s competitive advantages (most of which are qualitative) and how they translate into the return on capital.
On the flip side, every solid economic story should find a place in the numbers.
Brand name affects value, but it does so by increasing margins and excess returns, not as a premium at the end of the process.

 In relative valuation, toward storytelling sometimes overwhelms the numbers.
One reason for our use of statistical tools (regressions and correlations) in relative valuation is not only to assess whether the underlying story makes sense, but also to quantify the effects in our predictions.
Thus, by regressing PE against expected growth, we can measure how much the PE ratio increases for every 1% increase in the growth rate, at least given how the market is pricing stocks in this sector.

 Conclusion We end this book how we began it—by noting that valuation has only a few first principles, and that the basic structure of valuation has not changed much over time.
However, the kinds of firms we are called on to value pose more challenges today than ever before.
As firms and investors globalize, companies have become more complex in terms of both their operations and the financing choices they make to fund those operations.

 When called on to value companies, we should recognize that rigid rules do not serve us well, because valuing individual companies requires us to be flexible and devise new rules when faced with unusual scenarios.
Rather than let estimation issues overwhelm us and force us into bad choices, we should step back and assess commonsense ways, constrained by the data we have available, to deal with difficult issues.
